text:
Corridors of Power

Too early to talk about agenda of next NATO-Russia Council meeting - Russian
Foreign Ministry

MOSCOW. May 29 (Interfax) - The next meeting of the NATO-Russia Council has
not yet been decided on, and it is too early to talk about the agenda for the
event, Russian Foreign Ministry Department of European Cooperation Director
Nikolai Kobrinets told Interfax.

"The issue of holding the next meeting of the NATO-Russia Council has not been
decided yet. Therefore, it's too early to talk about the agenda for the
aforementioned event," Kobrinets said, in answer to a question from Interfax
as to whether a meeting of the NATO-Russia Council may take place soon.

Answering a question whether the withdrawal of the United States from the
Treaty on Open Skies will be brought up at the meeting of the council,
Kobrinets said, "We're using all available opportunities to build an equal
dialogue with the alliance, aimed at increasing transparency and deescalating
tensions in Europe. Senior Foreign Ministry officials have repeatedly voiced
Russia's stance on Washington's decision to unilaterally withdraw from the
Treaty on Open Skies."

Corridors of Power

Expansion of Russian military bases in Syria to broaden their functions,
improve security - State Duma member

MOSCOW. May 29 (Interfax) - The planned expansion of Hmeimim and Tartus,
Russian military bases in Syria, will improve their functionality and
security, Russian State Duma Defense Committee Deputy Chairman Yury Shvytkin
told Interfax.

"The functionality that Tartus has now is rather limited. It has been proposed
turning it into a proper naval base, which would have a broader spectrum of
functions in regard to servicing ships in the Mediterranean Sea, repairing
them, and naturally, carrying out strikes on terrorists, if necessary,"
Shvytkin said on Friday.

He went on to comment on the upcoming talks with Syria about transferring
additional immovable property and areas at sea to Russian military forces
under an agreement on the deployment of a Russian aviation group.

Regarding the Hmeimim base, Shvytkin said that he has visited it. "I can tell
you that the civil and the military airports as such are located very close to
each other. Of course, there's a need to separate them," he said.

"There is also a need to ensure the security of the military personnel and
equipment stationed at the Hmeimim base on distant approaches to the Hmeimim
base," Shvytkin said.

"The expansion will help our taskforce more effectively accomplish the tasks
set for it in the Syrian Arab Republic and, of course, defend the personnel
and armored vehicles at this base," he said.

Corridors of Power

Whelan getting full hospital assistance after hernia surgery - Russian Foreign
Ministry

MOSCOW. May 29 (Interfax) - Paul Whelan, who is accused of espionage in
Russia, is getting all necessary hospital assistance after a simple hernia
surgery, which he previously refused to undergo, the Russian Foreign Ministry
said.

Late at night on May 27, Whelan reached out to the administration of the
Lefortovo detention facility, complaining about a substantial deterioration of
his health due to an aggravation of a medical condition he had. He was sent to
the Sklifosovsky Institute of Emergency Care immediately after being examined
by doctors of a medical unit, the Foreign Ministry said in a statement on
Friday.

"In the early morning of May 28, Whelan was operated on. As we said earlier,
he previously refused to undergo this simple surgical intervention. He was
discharged from hospital and taken back to the detention center on May 29.
Paul Whelan is getting all quality curative care in the facility where he is
being held," the ministry said.

Corridors of Power

Putin approves Russia's counter-extremism strategy

MOSCOW. May 29 (Interfax) - Russian President Vladimir Putin has approved a
national strategy for countering extremism for the period to 2025.

The relevant decree was published on the official web portal for legal
information.

The current trend is toward further radicalization among certain groups of
population and the rise of external and domestic extremist threats, the
document said.

The strategy defines external extremist threats as "a number of states'
supporting and encouraging destructive activities by foreign or international
nongovernmental organizations, aimed at socio-political and socio-economic
destabilization in Russia, breaking the unity and territorial integrity of
Russia, including the instigation of 'color revolutions,' and at destroying
the traditional Russian spiritual and moral values."

Aiding international extremist and terrorist organizations, in particular by
propagating the extremist ideology and radicalism within society, also
qualifies as an external extremist threat.

"Internal extremist threats are attempts by nationalist, radical
nongovernmental, religious, ethnic and other organizations and groups and
certain individuals to carry out extremist activities to attain their own
goals," the strategy says.

Such activities involve promoting violence, inciting, recruiting or otherwise
engaging Russians and foreigners in Russia in extremist and other unlawful
activity, and forming closed ethnic and religious enclaves.

Some states are using extremism as a means to geopolitical ends such as
violating the territorial integrity of, or causing civil wars and "color
revolutions" in other states - their geopolitical adversaries, the document
said. "The real threat is posed by the recent rise in instances of intentional
distortion of history, the revival of the ideas of nationalism and fascism in
foreign states," the strategy says.

Information and telecommunications networks including the internet have become
a major recruitment tool used by extremist organizations. "Engaging various
groups of population to participate in unpermitted public gatherings
(including protests), which are deliberately transformed into mass
disturbances, is increasingly becoming a preferred method of causing socio-
political and socio-economic destabilization in Russia," the strategy says.

Corridors of Power

Putin signs decree on holding Victory Parade on June 24, declares it non-
working day - Kremlin

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Russian President Vladimir Putin has signed a
decree on holding military parades and artillery firework displays in
commemoration of the 75th anniversary of the Victory in the Great Patriotic
War of 1941-1945 and the Victory Parade of June 24, 1945, the Kremlin press
service said.

"In commemoration of the 75th anniversary of the Victory in the Great
Patriotic War of 1941-1945 and the Victory Parade of June 24, 1945, as a
gesture of gratitude to the conquerors of the Nazi invaders from their
descendants, paying a tribute to the great valor, heroism and selflessness of
the war veterans, I decree holding military parades on Red Square in Moscow
and in other cities of the Russian Federation at 10 a.m. local time on June
24, 2020, engaging weapons and military hardware and using the Victory Banner
as an official symbol of the Soviet people's Victory in the Great Patriotic
War, according to the established procedure," the document says.

The decree also orders conducting artillery firework displays in Moscow and
some other cities across Russia at 10:00 p.m. local time on June 24.

The document declares June 24 a paid non-working day.

The decree takes effect on the day of its signature.

Corridors of Power

U.S. position on Open Skies treaty, New START would ruin int'l security
architecture - Medvedev

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The United States' withdrawal from the Treaty on
Open Skies and Washington's position on the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty
(New START) are destroying the architecture of international security, Dmitry
Medvedev, Deputy Chairman of the Russian Security Council, said.

"The White House's position on these documents is leading to the destruction
of the architecture of international security and will have serious
consequences," Medvedev wrote on his Vk page.

He was among other Security Council permanent members who met with the
president earlier on Saturday to work out Russia's definitive position on the
U.S. withdrawal from the Open Skies treaty and the situation around New START.

Corridors of Power

Russian Foreign Ministry denies U.S. claims of sending Libya false Russian-
printed dinars seized in Malta

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The Russian Foreign Ministry has denied a claim by
the United States Department of State regarding the confiscation in Malta of
an equivalent of $1.1 billion of "counterfeit" Libyan dinars printed by the
Russian joint stock company Goznak for the eastern Libyan government.

"The contract to print Libyan dinars was signed in 2015 between Goznak and the
head of Libya's Central Bank approved by the Libyan House of Representatives
(parliament). The Libyan side made the required prepayment. In accordance with
its contractual obligations, the Russian organization sent the Central Bank in
Tobruk a shipment with the printed Libyan banknotes. We are working on the
premise that said money is needed to support the stable functioning of the
entire Libyan economy," the Russian Foreign Ministry said in a statement on
Saturday.

Because of the current duopoly in Libya, it has two central banks: one is in
Tripoli, the seat of the internationally recognized government of national
accord led by Fayez al-Sarraj, and the other is in Benghazi, whose governor
was appointed by an elected parliament, the House of Representative, and thus
possesses the necessary international legitimacy, the ministry said.

"Thus, it is not the Libyan dinars but U.S. claims that are false," the
statement said.

Corridors of Power

UN panel of experts on Libya found no sanctions breach in shipment of
banknotes to the country - Goznak

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The use of the term "false" toward the banknotes
seized in Malta, intended for the Central Bank of Libya, is unsubstantiated
and unlawful, the Russian joint stock company Goznak, which printed them,
said.

"The shipment of the print run in question was a subject of examination by the
UN Security Council panel of experts ono Libya, which found no violation of
the sanctions against this country in accordance with the UN Resolution No.
2259 (2019), which in turn was reflected in the panel's December 2019 report.
Goznak fulfilled all of its obligations under the aforesaid contract," the
company said.

"The banknotes made for this shipment are a modified series of previous
banknotes and are visually different from them. Samples of these banknotes
were approved by Libyan Central Bank representatives in an established manner;
therefore the application of the term 'false' toward these banknotes is
unsubstantiated and unlawful," Goznak said.

"As is known, the Central Bank of Libya has two offices, in Tripoli and in
Tobruk. The contract under which the batch of banknotes in question was
manufactured, was concluded by Goznak with the Central Bank of Libya office in
Tobruk," the company said.

"The commissioning of banknotes from Goznak was approved by the board of
directors of the Central Bank of Libya as far back as 2015. The right of the
Central Bank of Libya in Tobruk to conclude this kind of contract was, in
2016, reaffirmed by a resolution of the Government of National Accord
(Tripoli). Despite all the differences between the two sides, this decision
was not canceled and is valid to this day. The relevant contract with our
company was signed by a person vested with all necessary powers to that end,"
the company said.

"In violation of the norms of international law, in September of 2019 the
Malta Customs Authority detained containers with the banknotes belonging to
the Central Bank of Libya. Goznak, along with the customer, have repeatedly
sought to obtain explanations from Maltese authorities. For several months
Maltese customs agencies were providing no explanations over the seizure of
the banknotes, and only in May 2020 did they react with a statement whose
contents substantially misrepresents the actual circumstances surrounding the
relationship between Goznak and the Central Bank of Libya.

"We recommend that all other questions regarding the batch of banknotes in
question should be referred to their issuer, the Central Bank of Libya located
in Tobruk," Goznak said.

Earlier on Saturday, the Russian Foreign Ministry denied a claim by the United
States Department of State about the batch of Libyan dinars, printed by Goznak
for the eastern Libyan government and seized in Malta, being fake.

Corridors of Power

Russian envoy denies Moscow's involvement in violent protests in U.S.

BRUSSELS. June 1 (Interfax) - Russian Permanent Representative to
International Organizations in Vienna Mikhail Ulyanov has called the
allegations of Moscow's involvement in the wave of protests against the
killing of unarmed African American George Floyd by the police in the United
States unbelievable.

Susan Rice, former national security advisor in the Barack Obama
administration, said earlier she suspected Russia of being behind the violent
protests in the United States.

Rice said on CNN that both peaceful protesters and extremists were
participating in the demonstrations. "I would not be surprised to learn that
they have fomented some of these extremists on both sides using social media,"
Rice said.

"Unbelievable! But she is not kidding. She is absolutely serious. Demonisation
of Russians or brainwashing? Maybe both?" Ulyanov said on Twitter.

"As expected, the U.S. media has started speculating on the subject of Russia
being behind the riots in the United States. That's an illustrative example of
crisis phenomena in U.S. society. Instead of looking into the root of their
problems, they are looking for external 'culprits'," the diplomat said.

Flyod was detained by the Minneapolis police on May 25. An officer pressed
down his neck with a knee in the course of detention. Floyd died in a
hospital's ICU and a video of his detention was released online.

Corridors of Power

Allegations on Moscow's possible role in U.S. protests are 'erroneous
insinuations' - Kremlin

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The remarks by Susan Rice, former national
security advisor to United States President Barack Obama, suggesting that
Moscow might be behind the ongoing violent protests in the U.S. are erroneous
insinuations, which cannot reflect Washington's official views, Russian
presidential press secretary Dmitry Peskov said.

"First, we certainly are following what's happening in the U.S. very closely,
but everything that's happening there is the internal affair of that country.
We've never meddled in American affairs, and we aren't going to meddle now,
either," Peskov told journalists on Monday, when asked to comment on Rice's
remarks.

"Any insinuations, like the ones you've just mentioned, are of course
absolutely wrong and erroneous. And as far as we understand, such insinuations
cannot reflect Washington's official standpoint in any way," he said.

Corridors of Power

Allegations of Russia's involvement in violent protests in U.S. are fake -
Russian Foreign Ministry

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The Russian Foreign Ministry has described
allegations of Russia's involvement in violent protests in the United States,
which were triggered by the death of an African American man, George Floyd, at
the hands of the police, as propaganda and fake.

Susan Rice, former national security advisor in the Barack Obama
administration, said earlier she suspected Russia of being behind the violent
protests in the United States.

"In the past, your fellow party members made a fatal mistake: they created a
very silly concept suggesting that Russia should be blamed for everything you
don't like. Hillary Clinton and the entire Obama team convinced themselves and
tried to convince the world that domestic U.S. problems are created and
worsened by someone 'from the outside,' i.e., Russia," Russian Foreign
Ministry spokesperson Maria Zakharova said on Facebook.

"You're trying to make the same mistake by resorting, together with
journalists from CNN, to the dirty methods of manipulating information: there
are fake statements and zero facts to support them. Your interview with CNN is
the actual propaganda," Zakharova said.

Floyd was detained by the Minneapolis police on May 25. An officer pressed his
knee into Floyd's neck while detaining him. Floyd later died in a hospital's
ICU, and a video of his detention was released online.

Corridors of Power

No positive dynamics in summit-level dialogue with Ukraine, Georgia \- Peskov

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - For now, the Kremlin cannot affirm positive
dynamics in summit-level dialogue with Ukraine and Georgia, Russian
presidential press secretary Dmitry Peskov said.

"As for the leadership of those countries, unfortunately, for now, despite the
existence of certain contacts, we cannot boast of positive dynamics in the
summit-level dialogue," Peskov said in an interview with the TV program
"Moscow. Kremlin. Putin," aired on the Rossiya 24 (VGTRK) television channel.

He thus answered a question as to why Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky
was not invited to attend the Victory Parade in Moscow and whether this
decision could have been caused by his comments on WWII.

"First and foremost, the dynamics depend on how the heads of state keep their
promises and fulfill their obligations," Peskov said.

Peskov said that the Russian president congratulates the peoples of Ukraine
and Georgia on Victory Day every year, "because these are fraternal peoples,
who share deep, historical roots with us, and because Putin has a profound and
sincere respect for these peoples."

Corridors of Power

Armenian PM invited to Moscow to attend Victory Parade on June 24

YEREVAN. June 1 (Interfax) - Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan has
received an invitation from Russia to come to Moscow to attend a military
parade in commemoration of the 75th anniversary of the victory in the Great
Patriotic War, which is planned for June 24, the Armenian government press
service said.

Pashinyan thanked Russian President Vladimir Putin for the invitation in a
telephone call on Monday, the press service said.

"Nikol Pashinyan said he hopes he will recover by this date and will be able
to attend all events being planned in the context of the 75th anniversary of
Victory," it said.

Putin wished Pashinyan a happy birthday and the soonest possible recovery.

Pashinyan announced earlier on Monday that he and his family have been
diagnosed with the new coronavirus.

Corridors of Power

Russia tells Czech ambassador it is perplexed by Prague delaying bilateral
consultations - Russian Foreign Ministry

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Czech Ambassador in Moscow Vitezslav Pivonka has
been summoned to the Russian Foreign Ministry over Prague's postponement of
consultations on key bilateral issues, the Russian Foreign Ministry said.

"Ambassador of the Czech Republic to the Russian Federation Vitezslav Pivonka
was invited to the Russian Foreign Ministry on June 1. During a conversation
with First Deputy Foreign Minister of the Russian Federation Vladimir Titov,
the Czech diplomat was informed that Russia is perplexed by Prague delaying
consultations on key issues of Russian-Czech relations on the basis of the
August 26, 1993 Treaty on Friendly Relations and Cooperation between the
Russian Federation and the Czech Republic," the Foreign Ministry said in a
statement published on its website.

It was also noted at the meeting that the atmosphere accompanying bilateral
relations has considerably worsened recently, and a large number of problems,
which emerged not through Russia's fault, have accumulated.

"Russia is ready for dialogue on this matter, but continuing destructive steps
on the part of Czech authorities raise serious doubts about their willingness
to improve the situation. It was stressed that we will plan further steps in
relations with the Czech Republic depending on its reaction to our demarche,"
the ministry said.

Corridors of Power

Lavrov, Guterres discuss Syria, Libya, Covid-19 pandemic in phone call

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and United
Nations Secretary General Antonio Guterres discussed the situation in Libya,
the Syrian crisis, and the coronavirus pandemic, including in the context of
the World Health Organization's (WHO) role in tackling this problem, in a
telephone call, the Russian Foreign Ministry said on Monday.

"During the conversation, the participants gave particular attention to the
problem of the Syrian and Libyan settlement processes with a focus on
individual aspects of the UN's activities on these tracks, as well as to the
World Health Organization's work to respond to the consequences of the novel
coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic," the ministry said in a statement published
on its website.

"The Russian side noted the priority of appointing the head of the UN mission
in Libya as soon as possible amid the continuing degradation of the situation
in this country," it said.

In addition, Lavrov and Guterres "held an extensive exchange of opinions on
the situation "on the ground" in Syria, including Russia and Turkey's efforts
to stabilize the situation and maintain the ceasefire in the Idlib de-
escalation area within the framework of the Additional Protocol dated March 5
of this year," the ministry said.

"They also noted the threat of terrorists stepping up their activities in
Syria amid the coronavirus pandemic and stressed the need to ensure lasting
security and stability in the country on the basis of restoring its
sovereignty and territorial integrity," it said.

"The parties also discussed in detail the tasks of intensifying the delivery
of humanitarian aid to Syrians in need across the country's territory without
any discrimination, politicization, and preliminary conditions," the ministry
said.

"Lavrov reaffirmed Russia's support for the work of the UN and its specialized
institutions aimed at coordinating the member countries' efforts to overcome
the Covid-19 pandemic and its socioeconomic aftermath," it said.

"The sides also discussed ways to increase the effectiveness of global
cooperation in this field and broaden multilateral interaction on the platform
of this global organization," the ministry said.

Corridors of Power

Putin, Trump discuss by phone G7 summit, Covid-19, oil market

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Russian President Vladimir Putin and U.S.
President Donald Trump have discussed in a telephone call the situation
surrounding Covid-19, the Crew Dragon spacecraft launch, the G7 summit, as
well as the situation on the oil market, the Kremlin press service said.

"The parties have exchanged views on the measures taken in both countries to
counter coronavirus. Vladimir Putin expressed gratitude for the delivery of
U.S. ventilators to Russia," the press service said.

Putin congratulated his U.S. counterpart "on the successful launch of the Crew
Dragon crewed spacecraft, which took the U.S. astronauts to the International
Space Station, on May 30," it said. "Shared commitment to the development of
mutually beneficial cooperation in the field of space was reiterated," the
press service said.

The leaders of the two countries also addressed the situation on the global
oil market in the context of the implementation of the OPEC+ deal. "It was
stated that this multilateral agreement, reached with active support of the
presidents of Russia and the U.S., is leading to the gradual resumption of the
demand for oil and stabilization of prices," the Kremlin press service said.

"Donald Trump has informed [Putin] of his idea of holding the Group of Seven
summit and possibly inviting the leaders of Russia, Australia, India, and
South Korea," it said.

"The importance of intensifying the Russian-U.S. dialogue on strategic
stability and confidence-building measures in the military sector was noted,"
the press service said.

During the telephone call, the leaders agreed on the continuation of contacts
at various levels.

"The conversation was constructive, business-like and meaningful," the press
service said.

The telephone call took place at the initiative of the U.S. side, it said.

Corridors of Power

No evidence to uphold UN monitors' claim that Taliban maintaining ties with
al-Qaeda \- Russian diplomat

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Moscow sees no evidence to uphold the assertions
by UN monitors that the Taliban (banned in Russia) is continuing to maintain
ties with the terrorist group al-Qaeda (banned in Russia) in Afghanistan, even
despite its obligation not to do so under its agreement with the United
States, Russian presidential envoy for Afghanistan and Director of the Foreign
Ministry's Second Asian Department Zamir Kabulov said when commenting on a
recent report by a UN monitoring team.

"Not everything is so obvious about this report; there's no evidence presented
in it, only a lot of inference," Kabulov said in an interview with Interfax.

Members of the UN Analytical Support and Sanctions Monitoring Team earlier
issued a report alleging that the Taliban is continuing to maintain close
communication with al-Qaeda, despite its obligation to sever any links with
it, as stipulated by its agreement with the U.S.

"Concerns about al-Qaeda are, so to speak, a purely American thing," Kabulov
said.

"The Americans, I mean those who professionally deal with the situation in
Afghanistan, are perfectly aware that al-Qaeda is now a small international
terrorist group with no significant combat capability," he said.

Al-Qaeda is of symbolic significance for Americans, as U.S. forces were sent
to Afghanistan to fight this particular group, Kabulov said. "And they just
have to heighten al-Qaeda's profile, so as to rationalize their foreign
political ideology," he said.

Corridors of Power

Peskov on Donetsk's plan to hold victory parade: This is common history
bringing our peoples together

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Donetsk's plans to hold a military parade
commemorating the 75th anniversary of the Soviet Union's victory in the Great
Patriotic War show that the people there venerate common history, Russian
presidential press secretary Dmitry Peskov said.

"This could well be timed to coincide with the organization of a parade in
Moscow. The holding of a parade itself in commemoration of the remarkable date
of the 75th anniversary of the victory in the Great Patriotic War - and it's a
truly remarkable date for our peoples, it is common history that brings our
peoples together - this is something of which we can and should be proud,"
Peskov told journalists on Tuesday.

Asked to clarify which peoples he was talking about, Peskov said, "I'm talking
about our common nation, the victorious nation that conquered the Nazis and
saved Europe from the Nazis."

Head of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) Denis Pushilin
said earlier that Donetsk will hold a military parade on June 24 in
commemoration of the 75th anniversary of the victory in the 1941-1945 war.

Corridors of Power

Peskov says it's wrong to compare U.S. events with Russian issues

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - The protests sparked by the death of an African
American man named George Floyd as a result of his detention in the United
States have nothing in common with the Russian agenda, Kremlin spokesman
Dmitry Peskov said.

"I don't agree with your opinion that issues which are high on the U.S. public
agenda are somehow related to our agenda. We have our own agenda, and thank
God, what's going on in America isn't happening here," Peskov told journalists
in response to a question whether the Kremlin believes it will be necessary to
look into police conduct in the light of the events in the U.S.

When commenting on reports that Yekaterinburg police shot and killed a man
suspected of stealing four rolls of wallpaper, Peskov said, "Regretfully, you
and I are unaware of the details of the Yekaterinburg incident."

"You and I do not know for sure what happened there. It would be wrong to
discuss or comment on the issue without this knowledge," he said.

Corridors of Power

Putin, Trump did not discuss unrest in U.S. - Peskov

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - The current unrest in the United States, which was
triggered by the death of an African American man named George Floyd, was not
discussed in the phone call between Russian President Vladimir Putin and his
U.S. counterpart Donald Trump on Monday, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told
the press on Tuesday.

"No. That's not an issue of Russian-U.S. bilateral relations," Peskov said in
response to the relevant question.

If Russians residing in the United States need assistance or protection, they
will be provided with such, he said.

"There are Russian diplomatic missions and representative offices in the
United States. Of course, if citizens need protection, they'll receive it,"
Peskov said.

Corridors of Power

Moscow so far not invited to conversation among Normandy-format FMs - source

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Moscow has no information that a conversation
among the foreign ministers of the Normandy format member states is being
prepared, a Russian source told Interfax.

"We have no information on this conversation and haven't received any
invitations," the source said.

Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba said earlier on Tuesday that a
conversation among the foreign ministers of Ukraine, Germany, France, and
Russia would be arranged shortly.

Corridors of Power

Putin approves nuclear deterrence policy fundamentals

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Russian President Vladimir Putin has signed an
executive order to approve the fundamentals of Russia's nuclear deterrence
policy.

The document was published in the official database for legal information.

The order defines the fundamentals as "a strategic planning document in the
field of defense, which declares the official standpoint on the essence of
nuclear deterrence and identifies military threats and risks whose
neutralization is the purpose of nuclear deterrence, the principles of nuclear
deterrence, and the conditions under which Russia may resort to using nuclear
weapons."

Corridors of Power

Russia views nuclear weapons exclusively as means of deterrence, their use as
last resort - document

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Russia's nuclear deterrence policy is of a
defensive nature, and using nuclear weapons is a last resort, according to the
fundamentals of Russia's nuclear deterrence policy, which have been approved
by an executive order by Russian President Vladimir Putin.

"State policy in the field of nuclear deterrence has a defensive nature; it
aims to maintain the potential of nuclear forces at a level sufficient for
nuclear deterrence and which guarantees the sovereignty and territorial
integrity of the nation," the document says.

The state policy "will prevent, in case of a military conflict, an escalation
of hostilities and will bring them to a halt on terms acceptable to Russia and
its allies," the document says.

"Russia views nuclear weapons exclusively as a means of deterrence and their
use as a last resort and is taking every effort necessary to reduce the
nuclear threat and prevent an exacerbation of interstate relations which could
cause possible military conflicts, including nuclear ones," the document says.

Corridors of Power

Russia publishes list of key dangers due to which nuclear deterrence may be
used

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Russia may employ its nuclear deterrence
capabilities in case of threats of aggression against it resulting from
certain actions by potential adversaries, according to the fundamentals of
Russia's state nuclear deterrence policy, which were endorsed by Russian
President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday.

The presidential decree lists the key dangers which, depending on changes in
the military-political and strategic situation, may evolve into military
threats (threats of aggression) to Russia and for the neutralization of which
Russia shall employ its nuclear deterrence capabilities.

Among these dangers is "the buildup by a potential adversary of conventional
armed forces, including systems of nuclear weapons delivery, in territories
neighboring the Russian Federation and its allies and in adjacent sea areas,"
the decree published on the official online database for legal information
says.

"The deployment by states viewing the Russian Federation as a potential
adversary of missile defense systems and means, medium-range and shorter-
ranger cruise and ballistic missiles, precision-guided non-nuclear and
hypersonic weapons, unmanned combat aerial vehicles, and directed-energy
weapons" also constitutes a precondition for Russia to employ its nuclear
deterrence capabilities, according to the document.

The other dangers that may prompt Russia to use its nuclear deterrence
capabilities include "the development of missile defense and attack systems
and their deployment to outer space," "the possession by states of nuclear
weapons and (or) other types of weapons of mass destruction that may be used
against the Russian Federation and (or) its allies, as well as delivery
systems for such types of weapons," the uncontrollable proliferation of
nuclear weapons and their delivery systems, technology and equipment for their
manufacture, and "the deployment of nuclear weapons and systems for their
delivery to the territories of non-nuclear states."

Russia shall employ its nuclear deterrence capabilities with regard to
individual states and military coalitions (blocs, alliances) that view Russia
as a potential adversary and possess nuclear weapons and (or) other types of
weapons of mass destruction or substantial conventional force capabilities, it
says.

"In employing its nuclear deterrence capabilities, the Russian Federation
shall take into account potential adversary's deployment of offensive weapons

borders at a distance of 10 kilometers," Rudskoi said.

bombers in time, tracked them and took measures to prevent any incidents, he
said.

times. Anti-aircraft missile systems were on alert to be employed
immediately," Rudskoi said.

Coronavirus not preventing NATO from increasing number of exercises near
Russian borders - Russian General Staff

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The United States and NATO countries are
increasing their activities near the Russian border, despite the coronavirus
pandemic, head of the Russian General Staff's Main Operative Directorate
Sergei Rudskoi said.

"The Defense Ministry of the Russian Federation is constantly tracking and
registering a high level of military activity by the United States and its
allies in NATO near our borders. Despite the spread of the new coronavirus
infection around the world, there has been a considerable increase in NATO
combat training events that are clearly anti-Russian," Rudskoi told reporters
on Monday.

The largest exercise was the Defender Europe 2020 exercise, in which the
transfer of a U.S. contingent from the U.S. to Europe was envisaged, he said.

"The U.S. planned to involve in the exercise more than 28,000 troops, 287
tanks, 449 armored vehicles, and 95 helicopters. Another 17 countries planned
to form their contingents and involve five multinational units from SHAPE
[Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe]," Rudskoi said.

"This exercise was clearly anti-Russian," as practically all combat training
events were conducted on firing ranges near the Russian border, and facilities
on the territory of Russia were regarded as probable targets, he said.

"For example, landing operations in the Baltics and the Caucasus were expected
to be held before May 9 in these events. That didn't happen only due to
quarantine," Rudskoi said.

Attempts were made during the preparations for Defender Europe 2020 to bypass
the provisions of the Vienna document by dividing the large-scale training
into smaller parts and involving neutral states in the maneuvers," he said.

Chief of the General Staff of the Russian Armed Forces Valery Gerasimov many
times brought up this issue at talks last year and this year with NATO's
command in Europe, with former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Joseph
Dunford, current Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Mark Milley, and NATO
Military Committee Chairman Air Chief Marshal Stuart Peach, Rudskoi said.

At a meeting with NATO's Supreme Allied Commander in Europe Gen. Tod Wolters
in February this year, Russia once again reminded the alliance of its
initiative to transfer districts hosting large-scale operative and combat
training exercises deep inside the territory of border countries.

"All our suggestions aimed at reducing tensions and averting incidents were
outlined in Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov's letter to NATO Secretary
General Jens Stoltenberg. However, in actual fact, our suggestions were
ignored," Rudskoi said.

Russia to test Covid-19 vaccine on 50 volunteers from military personnel -
Russian Defense Ministry

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Russia is launching clinical trials of a Covid-19
vaccine on volunteers among Russian Armed Forces personnel, the Russian
Defense Ministry said on Tuesday.

"The Defense Ministry of Russia has finished selecting volunteers for clinical
trials of a one-of-a-kind domestically developed vaccine for the novel
coronavirus infection Covid-19. Fifty military personnel, among them five
women, who volunteered to take part in trials of the new vaccine, have been
selected for tests of the vaccine's safety and effectiveness," the ministry
said in a press release shared with Interfax.

The Covid-19 vaccine in question was developed with the help of the Russian
military, namely the Russian Defense Ministry's 48th Central Scientific
Research Institute, which will host the clinical trials.

specialized medical center at the 48th Central Scientific Research Institute
of the Russian Defense Ministry on June 3 to undergo a preliminary in-depth
health checkup and prepare for the experiment," the ministry said.

All candidates already underwent a preliminary health checkup and testing and
have not been diagnosed with any diseases for a month, it said.

The participants in the clinical trials were selected from different Armed
Forces units from all over the country, it said.

The clinical trials of the vaccine will be carried out on the premises of the
48th Central Scientific Research Institute, which previously hosted successful
trials of vaccines for Ebola, Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, and a
universal flu vaccine, the military said.

Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu told President Vladimir Putin on May 26
that clinical trials of the coronavirus vaccine will be completed before the
end of July.

The vaccine is being developed by the 48th Central Scientific Research
Institute of the Radiation, Chemical, and Biological Protection Troops of the
Defense Ministry together with the Nikolai Gamaleya National Epidemiology and
Microbiology Research Center of the Health Ministry. The 48th Central
Scientific Research Institute specializes in developing medical protection
against particularly dangerous diseases for the Armed Forces and the civilian
population.

located in the Moscow, Smolensk, Bryansk, Leningrad, Kaliningrad, Voronezh,

New Arctic research vessel undergo state trials in northern Russia

MOSCOW. June 3 (Interfax) - The Northern Fleet has begun state trials of the
Nikolai Skosyrev state-of-the-art hydrographic ship designed for Arctic
operations, the fleet's press service said.

"The Northern Fleet began the state trials of the Nikolai Skosyrev small
hydrographic vessel built by the Rybinsk-based Vympel shipyard today. It moved

will make its first outing to the Barents sea," the press service said in a

guidance for sea navigation in the Arctic. Its hull has been reinforced to an

Army

Sedov, Pallada sailing ships call on Vladivostok in the end of round-the-world
voyage

VLADIVOSTOK. June 3 (Interfax) - The Pallada and Sedov sailing ships of the
Federal Agency for Fishery, which had been on a round-the-world voyage
commemorating the 75th anniversary of the victory in the Great Patriotic War
and the 200th anniversary of the discovery of Antarctica, arrived in
Vladivostok on Wednesday, an Interfax correspondent reported from the
location.

The welcome ceremony for the Pallada was held at Pier 33 of Korabelnaya
Embankment, and the Sedov stayed anchored in the port's roadsteads for now.

The Pallada crew was presented with a round loaf of bread and a traditional
roasted piglet. The sailors were congratulated by Far Eastern State Technical
Fisheries University Rector Oleg Shcheka, who decorated Pallada captain
Nikolai Zorchenko and several crewmembers with medals on the occasion of the
completion of the round-the-world voyage.

"We saw you off on the round-the-world voyage from the same pier 216 days ago.
You fully accomplished your mission. We are proud that you have demonstrated a
high degree of professionalism and skills during this voyage. The second part
of the voyage, when the coronavirus infection started spreading throughout the
world and you had to skip a number of ports, was particularly difficult for
you and us, who were waiting for you on the ground. You coped with every
difficulty and once again proved to the entire world that Russian sailors are
the world's best," the rector said.

As reported earlier, the unique round-the-world expedition of sailing ships of
the Federal Agency for Fishery, Sails of Peace was dedicated to the 200th
anniversary of the discovery of Antarctica by Russian sailors and the 75th
anniversary of the victory in the Great Patriotic War.

The Pallada departed from Vladivostok on November 1, 2019. The Sedov and
Kruzenshtern barques left Kaliningrad on December 8, 2019. The three sailing
ships of the Federal Agency for Fishery had their first-ever rendezvous off
the Falkland Islands (Malvinas) and took part in the joint 200-mile regatta.

About 700 cadets of marine colleges and higher educational establishments of
the Federal Agency for Fishery had their internship with the ships' crews.

The Pallada covered a distance of over 26,000 nautical miles, including more
than 6,500 using the sails only. It crossed the Pacific, Atlantic and Indian
oceans, twice crossed the equator, and called on ports Apia (Samoa), Papeete
(Tahiti), Valparaiso (Chile), Ushuaia (Argentina), Cape Town (South Africa)
and Singapore.

The Sedov crossed the Baltic and North seas and the Atlantic and Indian
oceans. It covered a distance of about 20,000 nautical miles and called on
seven foreign ports. The Sedov will return to its home port, Kaliningrad, in
October.

base in Tajikistan have held an antiterrorism exercise, the Central Military
District press service said on Friday.

"The exercise, which was held simultaneously in two military towns in Dushanbe
and Bokhtar, involved about 500 servicemen and more than 20 pieces of military
hardware," the press service said.

inside a nonresidential building in Sunzha were identified. According to

Law Enforcement

Policeman who plead guilty in journalist Golunov case provides testimony
incriminating another suspect - source

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Denis Konovalov, a former policeman who earlier
confessed to planting narcotic drugs on journalist Ivan Golunov, said another
policeman, Akbar Sergaliyev, was aware of his actions on falsifying evidence,
a source familiar with some details of the investigation said.

"Konovalov said while being questioned face-to-face with Sergaliyev that the
latter was aware that their superior, Igor Lyakhovets, had instructed him to
back up the results of the search and investigative procedures," the source
told Interfax on Friday.

Golunov was questioned face-to-face with Sergaliyev as part of the
investigation on Friday, he said.

"According to Konovalov, the other people implicated in the case could have
figured out what he did, but he himself did not say this to them," he said.

The results of Konovalov's questioning using a lie detector were ready, the
source said.

On June 2, Moscow's Basmanny District Court is to hear the investigation's
request on extending the pretrial custody term for four former policemen
indicted in the Golunov case until September 7. The investigation has also
asked the court to extend the term of Konovalov's house arrest until the same
date.

The Basmanny District Court ruled on January 30 to arrest Igor Lyakhovets, a
senior official from the drug control division of the police department for
Moscow's Western Administrative District, as well as four of his former
subordinates, i.e. Denis Konovalov, Roman Feofanov, Akbar Sergaliyev, and
Maxim Umetbayev, who were involved in detaining Golunov in June 2019.

The police officials are charged with abuse of office, falsification of
evidence, and illegal drug trafficking. Konovalov was later granted house
arrest at the investigation's request.

Golunov was detained on June 6, 2019, and charged with intent to deal drugs.
The criminal charges were dropped on June 11, due to a public outcry.

The five police officials involved in detaining Golunov and chief of the
police department for Moscow's Western Administrative District Andrei Puchkov
were discharged from police at about the same time.

It emerged on December 19, 2019 that a criminal case had been opened into
Golunov's detention on a count of abuse of office by police officials. Golunov
said in February that he had received apologies for his wrongful prosecution
from the prosecutor's office for Moscow's Western Administrative District.

Law Enforcement

Group of FSB officers to be subpoenaed to come to court as part of Set case

ST. PETERSBURG. June 1 (Interfax) - The 2nd Western Military District Court
has ruled partly in favor of a request filed by defendant Viktor Filinkov's
legal team to subpoena the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) officers who
detained Filinkov for questioning at its visiting session in St. Petersburg as
part of the trial of the Set terrorist organization (banned in Russia).

"The request shall be partly granted [...] [FSB officers] Belyayev, Tokarev,
Bondarev, and Shepelev shall be subpoenaed to appear in court as witnesses,"
Judge Roman Muranov said on Monday, adding that "the court will take all
necessary measures to ensure this interrogation," scheduled for Tuesday.

The FSB officers took part in Filinkov's detention and helped draw up relevant
investigative documents.

A lawyer for another defendant, Vitaly Cherkasov, also requested an interview
from officers from FSB's Penza branch, but the court dismissed the request.

Filinkov said in court earlier that FSB officers subjected him to physical
violence after detaining him and forced him to learn his confession by heart.
Linguistic experts, in turn, concluded that fragments of the minutes of the
testimony given by Filinkov and Ilya Shakursky, who was identified during the
trial as one of the Set organization's leaders and was convicted as part of
the same case in Penza, are identical and were most likely compiled by one and
the same person.

Filinkov, 25, and Yury Boyarshinov, 27, are on trial in St. Petersburg in the
Set case. Filinkov has not admitted guilt. He told the court that he confessed
under torture. Boyarshinov has agreed with the charge.

There are 11 defendants from Penza, St. Petersburg, and Moscow in the Set
case, which Russia's Federal Security Service has been investigating since
fall 2017. According to the FSB, young anarchists set up a group to plot
terror attacks during the presidential election and the FIFA World Cup, as
well as to destabilize Russia.

On February 10, during a visiting session in Penza, the Volga District
Military Court sentenced seven defendants to six to 18 years in prison. The
defendants pleaded not guilty and said they earlier confessed under torture.

organization's leaders and was convicted as part of the same case in Penza,
are identical and were most likely compiled by the same person.

Filinkov, 25, and Yury Boyarshinov, 27, are on trial in St. Petersburg in the
Set case. Filinkov has not admitted guilt. He told the court that he confessed
under torture. Boyarshinov has agreed with the charge.

There are 11 defendants from Penza, St. Petersburg, and Moscow in the Set
case, which Russia's Federal Security Service has been investigating since
fall 2017. According to the FSB, young anarchists set up a group to plot
terror attacks during the presidential election and the FIFA World Cup, as
well as to destabilize Russia.

On February 10, during a visiting session in Penza, the Volga District
Military Court sentenced seven defendants to six to 18 years in prison. The
defendants pleaded not guilty and said they earlier confessed under torture.

Court extends pretrial custody term for ex-policemen charged in Golunov case
until Sept

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Moscow's Basmanny District Court has ruled to
extend the pretrial custody term of four former police officials accused of
falsifying evidence against journalist Ivan Golunov, the court press service
told Interfax on Tuesday.

"The court has granted the investigation's request on extending the custody
term until September 7, 2020," it said.

The defense for the defendants insisted on easing the pretrial restraint
measures imposed on their clients. In particular, a defense attorney for Roman
Feofanov argued that the latter was held in the same cell with ten other
mates, some of whom showed symptoms of the new coronavirus infection,
including fever and the loss of the sense of smell. The coronavirus test of
Feofanov himself was not ready yet, the lawyer said.

The court had also ruled on Monday to extend the duration of house arrest of
Denis Konovalov, another policeman implicated in the case.

As reported, during face-to-face interrogations Konovalov admitted his guilt
and testified against his chief Igor Lyakhovets, who, according to
investigators, is a plotter of the crime. The former policeman also testified
against another fellow police officer Akbar Sergaliyev last week, an informed
source told Interfax.

Golunov was detained on June 6, 2019, and was charged with attempting to sell
drugs. The criminal charges against the journalist were dropped on June 11,
2019, amid a wide public campaign in support of him. Golunov said the drugs
had been planted on him and assumed that the attempt to implicate him in a
crime was prompted by his journalistic investigation related to the funeral
business that he had been working on before his detention.

The Basmanny District Court ruled on January 30 to arrest Igor Lyakhovets, a
senior official from the drug control division of the police department for
Moscow's Western Administrative District, as well as four of his former
subordinates, i.e. Denis Konovalov, Roman Feofanov, Akbar Sergaliyev, and
Maxim Umetbayev, who were involved in detaining Golunov in June 2019. The
investigation concluded that the policemen, acting on Lyakhovets's orders,
procured the drugs and planted them on the journalist to implicate him in the
crime.

The police officials are currently charged with abuse of office combined with
violence, the use of special means and causing grave consequences, as well as
falsification of evidence, and illegal drug trafficking on a large scale.

Law Enforcement

Dozens of thousands of unjustly convicted people in Russia, up to 1,000
political prisoners - human rights center

MOSCOW. June 3 (Interfax) - The human rights center Memorial has estimated the
number of unjustly convicted people in Russia at dozens of thousands and the
number of political prisoners at 2-3 times more than the 300 people Memorial
knows of.

"The understanding of the state of the Russian law enforcement and judicial
system makes it possible to believe it is probable that the number of innocent
people whose guilt was not proven in accordance with the procedures
established by the law in Russia is at least in the dozens of thousands. Such
estimations are given by human rights experts and victims of this system, who
had to personally experience it," Memorial told Interfax on Tuesday.

Moscow Memorial board member Sergey Davidis told the agency regarding the
number of political prisoners, in other words, people prosecuted for political
reasons, that "bearing in mind the number of existing cases which we know of
and believe to have indications of political motivation and illegal
prosecution in them, but which we could not investigate properly, I think the
total number of political prisoners is 2-3 times more than the 314 people who
are currently on our lists."

The number of known political prisoners has increased more than six times
since 2015.

The Memorial report on the situation with politically motivated prosecutions
states that "an overwhelming majority of political prisoners are people
imprisoned in connection with the exercise of the right to freedom of religion
and religious affiliation."

In regard of the prosecution of activists and the excessively broad practice
of the use of some provisions of the legislation, Memorial demands the
scrapping of the article on repeat violations of the regulations governing the
organization of rallies, insulting the feelings of believers, public calls for
violations of Russia's territorial integrity, willful evasion of the
observance of duties envisaged by the legislation on foreign agent NGOs,
"revision of the practice of the use of the extremist legislation, serious
revision and updating of the anti-extremist and counterterrorism legislation."

Dmitry Vyatkin, first deputy head of the State Duma Committee for the
Development of Civil Society, told Interfax that "there are no political
prisoners in Russia as we do not have political articles."

"Communities, organizations, citizens who start using terms such as 'political
prisoners,' 'prisoners of conscience' pursue their goals, which are far from
human rights protection as such," Vyatkin said. He said he believes that is "a
consequence of the work that is being done against Russia, which consists of
deliberate provocations, attempts to destabilize the situation." "We do not
idealize the law enforcement system of any country, but the attempts to reduce
everything to politics - no, it's not politics," he said.

"None of the articles stated [in the Memorial report] can be reversed,
especially Article 282 (organization of an extremist community), it should be
used and fulfill its function because dividing society, destabilizing, playing
on low feelings, dividing [people] into first and second class [citizens] -
these things are very dangerous, it may blow up any country," he said.

The human rights center Memorial has been on the foreign agent list since
2014.

Captain of N. Korean vessel receives 1.5 years in prison for state border
violation, poaching

VLADIVOSTOK. June 3 (Interfax) - A court in Russia's Primorye Territory has
sentenced the captain of a North Korean schooner to 1.5 years in prison for a
violation of the Russian state border and illegal crabbing.

The captain was sentenced to 1.5 years in a settlement colony, according to
the materials of the Khasan District Court, where the case was tried.

The foreign fishing vessel, which was carrying another six crewmembers, left
port in November 2019. The vessel illegally crossed the Russian state border
without identification signs or a traffic control system. The foreign
fishermen illegally fished 1,180 opilio crabs in the Peter the Great Gulf off
the coast of Primorye. The vessel was detained by Russian border guards.

The poached crabs were released into the sea.

An informed source told Interfax the defendant is a citizen of North Korea.

The criminal case was tried in accordance with special proceedings, and the
defendant agreed with the charge.

The court took into account the defendant's full confession, his cooperation
with investigators, and the fact that he has a young child.

The sentence has gone into legal effect.

Russian Supreme Court turns down prosecution's motion on reviewing ex-
policeman Zakharchenko's case

MOSCOW. June 4 (Interfax) - The Russian Supreme Court has turned down a
cassation motion by the Prosecutor General's Office on the case of Dmitry
Zakharchenko, a former colonel of the Russian Interior Ministry's Anti-
Corruption Directorate, who was sentenced to 12 years and six months of prison
for bribery and obstruction of justice.

"The court turned down the motion on transferring the case to a cassation
instance for hearing," the court's press service told Interfax on Wednesday.

The cassation motion was filed with the Supreme Court by Deputy Prosecutor
General Viktor Grin, it said.

Moscow's Presnensky District Court ruled on June 10, 2019 to sentence
Zakharchenko to 13 years in a high-security penitentiary for accepting a
massive bribe and obstructing justice, fined him 117,990,000 rubles, and
stripped him of his colonel's rank and decorations.

The first-instance court cleared Zakharchenko of one of the two bribery counts
he was charged with and ruled that he was entitled to rehabilitation.

After hearing the prosecution's motion and the defense's complaints, the
Moscow City Court ruled on October 17, 2019 to commute the prison term given
to Zakharchenko to 12 years and six months. The court, however, left the extra
punishments given to him, including the fine, unchanged.

The 2nd General Jurisdiction Cassation Court ruled on February 18, 2020 to
uphold the judgments handed down in Zakharchenko's case. The court declined
both the prosecution's motion, in which it requested that the count of which
he was cleared be reviewed in a first-instance court, and the defense's
complaint, in which it insisted on the former policeman's complete acquittal.

The investigation determined that Zakharchenko received a 50% discount card
for the La Maree fish restaurant chain from businessman Mehdi Duss, which
saved him about 3 million rubles.

The investigation and the court also determined that Zakharchenko had warned
Galina Marchukova, the financial director of Nota Bank, of impending searches
in 2016.

Zakharchenko was also charged with receiving, together with former Federal
Security Service (FSB) officer Dmitry Senin, a $800,000 bribe from Duss, but
the court cleared him of this crime.

In 2020, Zakharchenko was also charged with accepting bribes amounting to
about 1.5 billion rubles, after which he was escorted from a penitentiary in
Mordovia to Moscow to be familiarized with the new case.

Zakharchenko made headlines after detectives discovered cash in different
currencies amounting in aggregate to an equivalent of some 8 billion rubles in
his sister's apartment.

The former colonel, who was arrested back on September 10, 2016, described the
criminal cases opened against him as fake.

MOSCOW. June 5 (Interfax) - A court in Moscow has partially granted a police

"The administrative legal application from the head of Kuntsevo district

events, leaving the home region or dwelling within certain hours, and required

March 22, 2017 the Supreme Court upheld the conviction.

Covid-19 vaccine developed jointly with Russian military ready for clinical
trials

MOSCOW. June 5 (Interfax) - Preparations have been completed for the start of
clinical trials of a Covid-19 vaccine, which has been developed by the Russian
military together with the Nikolai Gamaleya National Epidemiology and
Microbiology Research Center, employee of a branch of the Burdenko Main
Military Hospital Natalya Pozdnyakova said.

Fifty volunteers have been selected among Russian Armed Forces personnel for
participation in the clinical trials, while the vaccine itself have already
undergone tests for toxicity, safety, immunogenicity, and protective
efficiency on large and small animals (monkeys and hamsters) at the 48th
Central Scientific Research Institute of the Russian Defense Ministry, she
said.

"In such a way, the Defense Ministry together with the Nikolai Gamaleya
National Epidemiology and Microbiology Research Center has completed
preparations for the start of clinical trials of this unique domestic vaccine
for the Covid-19 coronavirus infection," the Defense Ministry's Krasnaya
Zvezda newspaper quoted Pozdnyakova as saying.

During the selection of candidates, each volunteer was required to undergo a
full range of medical examinations, she said.

A separate, isolated hospital building was allocated for the selected
volunteers, who include 45 men and five women. Prior to that, the building was
fully disinfected and all of its premises were sanitized. The volunteers were
transported to the site of the experiment by previously disinfected vehicles.

"All of them are serving under contract. They are warrant officers and
officers aged between 25 and 50 years old, since legislation of the Russian
Federation prohibits conducting trials on conscripts," Pozdnyakova said.

These 50 volunteers include ten healthcare workers, including three doctors.

Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu told President Vladimir Putin during a
videoconference on May 26 that the 48th Central Scientific Research Institute
of the Radiation, Chemical, and Biological Protection Troops of the Defense
Ministry together with the Nikolai Gamaleya National Epidemiology and
Microbiology Research Center are developing a recombinant vaccine for the
novel coronavirus. Clinical trials of the vaccine are expected to be completed
before the end of July.

Soyuz MS-17 crew approved for ISS mission this fall

MOSCOW. May 29 (Interfax) - The crew of the Soyuz MS-17 spaceship that will
head to the International Space Station (ISS) in October will include Russian
cosmonauts Sergei Ryzhikov and Sergei Kud-Sverchkov, as well as NASA astronaut

Babkin.

It was reported earlier this month that Novitsky, Dubrov, Kud-Sverchkov, and
Ryzhikov had arrived in the United States to train for the ISS flight.

The Soyuz MS-17 was scheduled to launch in October 2020. Roscosmos executive
director for manned missions Sergei Krikalyov said that for the first time in
20 years, the crew was to be made up of only Russians. However, later, because
the U.S. manned spaceships were not ready, NASA asked Roscosmos for additional
seats on Soyuz spaceships.

Initially, the main crew of the Soyuz MS-17 was to include Anatoly Ivanishin
and Ivan Vagner, but they were sent to the ISS on board Soyuz MS-16, instead
of the main crew's Andrei Babkin and Nikolai Tikhonov, who were barred from
the flight for medical reasons.

Roscosmos on Crew Dragon's launch: It is very important to have two options of
traveling to ISS

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The Russian state space corporation Roscosmos has
welcomed Saturday's successful launch of the manned aircraft Crew Dragon in
the U.S. and noted the importance of a co-existence of two transport systems
that can deliver crews to the International Space Station.

"It is very important to have at least two opportunities to get to the
station. Since you never know... Things have happened in space, and there
should be at least two transport systems capable of ensuring the presence of
crews from different countries on board the ISS," Roscosmos spokesman Vladimir
Ustimenko wrote on Twitter.

Commenting on the successful launch of Crew Dragon, Ustimenko said, "What has
happened should have happened a long time ago. Now not only the Russians but
also the Americans will fly to the ISS. That's great!"

As reported earlier, a SpaceX capsule carrying two NASA astronauts docked at
the ISS at 5:16 p.m. Moscow time on Sunday.

Crew Dragon, on board of which two NASA astronauts, Robert Behnken and Douglas
Hurley, departed from Cape Canaveral in Florida on Saturday afternoon to reach
the ISS in about 19 hours, is the first manned aircraft launched form the U.S.
since 2011, when the final space shuttle mission was completed.

The two U.S. astronauts lifted off in SpaceX's Crew Dragon spacecraft on a
Falcon 9 rocket from Launch Complex 39A in Florida at 3:22 p.m. EDT on May 30.
Initially, the launch was due earlier on May 27 but ended up being delayed 15
minutes to blast-off due to bad weather.

The launch was performed under the contract between NASA and SpaceX on
creating an aircraft and a launch vehicle for commercial manned missions to
the ISS.

This Crew Dragon mission is the spaceship's last big trial before a NASA
certification for regular commercial manned missions to the ISS. In March
2019, a similar pilotless spacecraft completed the first successful
experimental spaceflight to the station.

Since 2011, U.S. astronauts had been using Russia's Soyuz spacecraft to reach
the ISS. NASA pays Russia for seats on board a Soyuz spacecraft. In
particular, This May, NASA agreed to pay Roscosmos $90.2 million for one seat
on board the Soyuz, which is due to depart for the ISS on October.

Roscosmos head Dmitry Rogozin said on May 25 that Russia was following with
interest preparations for the launch of the manned spacecraft Crew Dragon to
the ISS. The return of Americans to this work will help increase the number of
Russian cosmonauts on board the station, he said.

"It is with great interest that we're watching the preparations for this
launch. We have several motives for this. Indeed, for the past nine years,
since summer 2011, only Russia, only Roscosmos, has facilitated the delivery
of all international crews to the ISS: Americans, Europeans, the Japanese, and
Canadians," Rogozin said on the Komsomolskaya Pravda radio station.

"Yes, we have, of course, made some money on that, but in fact, the
responsibility associated with supporting this transport system, the continual
delivery to the ISS, has been colossal; it's not worth the money: the cost is
nerves, the health of the people in charge of manned space," Rogozin said.

"We would be very happy if the Americans came up with an alternative manned
transport system. It's a natural process, such a great power as the U.S., I
imagine what they went through all these nine years, not being able to deliver
astronauts to the ISS on their spacecraft [...] Let's wish them professional
success," he said.

Russia is also interested in the technical side of the project, Rogozin said.

Unburdening Russian spacecraft will help increase the number of cosmonauts on
the station, he said. "We've reduced our crews to two cosmonauts, who are in
orbit continually. Sometimes there was only one, the captain, in orbit. This
is wrong. This hinders the entire scientific program which we associate with
the ISS," Rogozin said.

Dozens of thousands of unjustly convicted people in Russia, up to 1,000
political prisoners - human rights center

MOSCOW. June 3 (Interfax) - The human rights center Memorial has estimated the
number of unjustly convicted people in Russia at dozens of thousands and the
number of political prisoners at 2-3 times more than the 300 people Memorial
knows of.

"The understanding of the state of the Russian law enforcement and judicial
system makes it possible to believe it is probable that the number of innocent
people whose guilt was not proven in accordance with the procedures
established by the law in Russia is at least in the dozens of thousands. Such
estimations are given by human rights experts and victims of this system, who
had to personally experience it," Memorial told Interfax on Tuesday.

Moscow Memorial board member Sergey Davidis told the agency regarding the
number of political prisoners, in other words, people prosecuted for political
reasons, that "bearing in mind the number of existing cases which we know of
and believe to have indications of political motivation and illegal
prosecution in them, but which we could not investigate properly, I think the
total number of political prisoners is 2-3 times more than the 314 people who
are currently on our lists."

The number of known political prisoners has increased more than six times
since 2015.

The Memorial report on the situation with politically motivated prosecutions
states that "an overwhelming majority of political prisoners are people
imprisoned in connection with the exercise of the right to freedom of religion
and religious affiliation."

In regard of the prosecution of activists and the excessively broad practice
of the use of some provisions of the legislation, Memorial demands the
scrapping of the article on repeat violations of the regulations governing the
organization of rallies, insulting the feelings of believers, public calls for
violations of Russia's territorial integrity, willful evasion of the
observance of duties envisaged by the legislation on foreign agent NGOs,
"revision of the practice of the use of the extremist legislation, serious
revision and updating of the anti-extremist and counterterrorism legislation."

Dmitry Vyatkin, first deputy head of the State Duma Committee for the
Development of Civil Society, told Interfax that "there are no political
prisoners in Russia as we do not have political articles."

"Communities, organizations, citizens who start using terms such as 'political
prisoners,' 'prisoners of conscience' pursue their goals, which are far from
human rights protection as such," Vyatkin said. He said he believes that is "a
consequence of the work that is being done against Russia, which consists of
deliberate provocations, attempts to destabilize the situation." "We do not
idealize the law enforcement system of any country, but the attempts to reduce
everything to politics - no, it's not politics," he said.

"None of the articles stated [in the Memorial report] can be reversed,
especially Article 282 (organization of an extremist community), it should be
used and fulfill its function because dividing society, destabilizing, playing
on low feelings, dividing [people] into first and second class [citizens] -
these things are very dangerous, it may blow up any country," he said.

The human rights center Memorial has been on the foreign agent list since
2014.

LPR head lifts high alert in self-proclaimed republic's forces

LUHANSK. June 3 (Interfax) - Head of the self-proclaimed Luhansk People's
Republic (LPR) Leonid Pasechnik has announced the lifting of the high alert
regime enacted in the LPR armed forces on May 20.

"Ukraine fulfilled the demands of the Luhansk People's Republic and ceased
attacks on our territory. We haven't observed any truce violations and other
provocations for almost a week. In this context, I've made a decision to
reduce the level of combat readiness in militia units," Pasechnik said in a
statement shared with Interfax on Wednesday.

The LPR "is interested in an escalation least of all," he said.

"Our people need peace. However, I want to stress straight away that any
provocation or a breach of the ceasefire by armed formations of Ukraine will
be met with an appropriate response: [LPR forces] will again be put on high
alert, and any aggression from armed formations of Ukraine will draw an
appropriate reaction from militia servicemen," he said.

Pasechnik put the LPR militia on high alert on May 20 in order to prevent an
escalation of the conflict by Ukraine on the contact line in Donbas. The
neighboring self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) did the same.

Newly Independent States

Lukashenko dismisses Belarusian government

MINSK. June 3 (Interfax) - Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko has
signed a decree to dismiss the government.

"The [Belarusian] president has decided to dismiss the current government. A
relevant decree has been signed," the state television Belarus 1 reported.

Lukashenko held a meeting on Wednesday, on which proposals on the composition
of the next government were discussed. The head of state promised that there
would be no revolutionary changes in the government.

Lukashenko announced on May 25 that he was planning to put together a new
government before the presidential election, which is scheduled for August 9.

"Following the incumbent president's registration as a presidential candidate,
we have always announced a new government composition prior to the election,"
he said.

"It's a crucial issue, so that people see with whom we'll be working,"
Lukashenko said, adding that such a step is taken in order to enhance voter
trust.

"Or what? The election has passed, people voted for you... But you're pushing
your relatives, your loved ones, your family, or others into this government,"
he said.

Belarus's current government, led by Prime Minister Sergei Rumas, has been
working since August 18, 2018, after Lukashenko dismissed Andrei Kobyakov's
government, accusing it of mismanagement during the implementation of a
development program for the country's Orsha district.

Newly Independent States

Dodon hopes Planotniuc to be extradited to Moldova from U.S.

CHISINAU. June 4 (Interfax) - Moldovan President Igor Dodon said he believes
it is highly likely that the United States would extradite fugitive tycoon
Vladimir Plahotniuc.

"The Prosecutor General's Office is actively working on this track. The proof
of Plahotniuc's guilt causes no doubt. I don't know the details due to the
secrecy of investigation, but I know that the work is underway. As soon as the
indictment is translated into English, they will be sent to the U.S. so that
the extradition begins," Dodon said live on air at the Sputnik Moldova radio
station on Wednesday evening.

Answering the station's questions, he strongly denied statements made by
Plahotniuc's lawyers, who said on Tuesday that the criminal case against his
client "is politically motivated."

"Everyone understands that there is no politics here. Not only are we talking
about it, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stated this early this year
after adding Plahotniuc to the U.S. sanctions list due to the crimes he had
committed," the president said.

He said he is confident that Plahotniuc's extradition would be secured, "if
only geopolitics does not interfere, if someone does not want to use the
fugitive oligarch for geopolitical purposes to influence the political
situation in the country through him."

Moldova intends to seek not only Plahotniuc's extradition from the U.S., but
also Ilan Shor's extradition from Israel, despite the fact that Moldova does
not have signed extradition agreements with those countries, Dodon said.

"Perhaps that's why they fled there. However, our situation involving Israel
is different than the U.S. I don't think the leadership of Israel may have any
interest to use Shor in some political game in Moldova. Ilan Shor must be
convicted and he will serve a sentence, if not in Moldova, then in Israel,"
Dodon said.

"Moldova has signed a strategic partnership agreement with the U.S.,
therefore, there's a hope that Plahotniuc will be extradited, the Prosecutor
General's Office makes all possible effort to that end," he said.

The former leader of Moldova's Democratic Party, main Moldovan tycoon
Plahotniuc, left Moldova in the evening of June 14, 2019, when the Democratic
Party had become the opposition. He is in Miami, as confirmed by the U.S.
Embassy in Moldova.

On January 13, U.S. Secretary of State Michael Pompeo said that Plahotniuc and
his family were placed on the U.S. sanctions list due to the oligarch's
involvement in "significant corruption."

In May, Moldovan Prosecutor General Alexandr Stoianoglo said that Plahotniuc
was the main beneficiary of a $1 billion theft from the country's banking
system, and was now facing three criminal charges: setting up an organized-
crime group, extortion, and massive fraud.

On May 22, the court made a decision based on these charges to sanction
Plahotniuc's 30-day-long arrest in absentia.

In Russia Plahotniuc is a subject of several criminal inquiries. On July 29,
2019, Moscow's Tverskoi court arrested him in absentia. Then in November the
same court decided to arrest Plahotniuc for two months from the moment of his
apprehension in or extradition to Russia.

Ukraine's new deputy PM Stefanyshyna hoping for teamwork among all branches of
power on integration into EU, NATO

KYIV. June 4 (Interfax) - Ukraine integrating into the European Union and NATO
means teamwork among all branches of power, Ukraine's newly elected Deputy
Prime Minister for European and Euro-Atlantic Integration Olha Stefanyshyna
said.

"Work in the direction of the EU and NATO is teamwork. It's impossible to
implement these reforms without interaction with the parliament, the
president, and the government, and therefore, I believe that the post of
deputy prime minister is the post of the operational manager of this process,
who will ensure the daily achievement of big results," Stefanyshyna said at a
plenary session of parliament on Thursday.

European integration is a natural process for Ukraine, and "it's important to
ensure that the process of European, Euro-Atlantic integration is carried out
particularly on the basis of the national interests of Ukraine, on the
condition of coordinated work among all branches of power, coordinated work in
the government," she said.

Among the priorities that will be included in her area of responsibility,
Stefanyshyna mentioned the protection of national goods, national commodity
manufacturers, and national economic security, which can be provided for when
changes are made to the association agreement between Ukraine and the EU in
early 2021.

She also said it is necessary to hold talks on increasing non-credit financing
from international partners, Ukraine's access to transborder cooperation, and
expansion of bilateral cooperation with neighboring countries on
infrastructure projects and the liberalization of trade services.

Among her three main priorities, Stefanyshyna mentioned the formation of the
internal position of the format and volume of revision of the association
agreement, revision of the conditions of financing for Ukraine, and the
establishment of effective interaction among the branches of power.

Normandy summit to be held in Berlin this year - Ukrainian presidential office

KYIV. June 4 (Interfax) - Head of the Ukrainian presidential office Andriy
Yermak has said he hopes that the leaders of the Normandy format states will
meet in Berlin in 2020.

"I'm certain that the summit of the heads of state and governments of Germany,
France, Ukraine, and Russia will be held in Berlin this year," Yermak said in
