Lukashenko pledges to protect Belarus's sovereignty so that Belarusians aren't
sent to fight in Syria, Libya

MINSK. June 4 (Interfax) - Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko has
pledged to do everything necessary to preserve Belarus's sovereignty and
independence.

"We inherited the country and built our first independent and sovereign state.
We won't give this country away to anyone and won't allow it to be tortured,
destabilized day after day, torn into pieces and handed out," the Belarusian
state-run news agency BelTA quoted Lukashenko as saying at a meeting on the
composition of the new Belarusian government on Thursday.

There is an impression that certain potential presidential candidates "seek to
destabilize and turn the country upside down using somebody else's money," he
said.

"You and everyone else who hears me should remember that they won't get our
country. We have spent over two decades picking up crumbs and building this
prosperous country, and we won't allow anyone to privatize it and to bleed dry
the unlucky fellows who have always lived under a whip," Lukashenko said.

"We won't allow Belarus to be divided, as happened in 1939," he said.

"We've built our country for our children. It's time we protect and defend it.
As you can see, they're trying to tear us apart," Lukashenko said. "Some think
everything will fall out of the sky. Watch out, or else you'll be sent to
fight in Syria and Libya. God help us avoid fighting for our land and
defending it," he said.

Some 50% of Ukrainians support integration with EU, more than 40% support
Ukraine's accession to NATO - poll

KYIV. June 5 (Interfax) - A total of 46.1% of Ukrainians believe the country
should join the European Union, and 41.9% of citizens support Ukraine's
accession to NATO, according to a poll conducted by the Kyiv International
Institute of Sociology (KIIS).

According to the poll, which was presented at the Interfax press center on
Friday, 34.7% of Ukrainians believe that Ukraine should be a neutral state,
12% believe it should be a member of the Collective Security Treaty
Organization (CSTO), 13.1% support the country's accession to the Eurasian
Economic Union (EAEU), and 28.3% believe the country should not join any of
those unions.

A total of 27.1% of respondents said they would move to the United States or
the European Union to live there permanently, if they were granted U.S. or EU
citizenship, and 65.1% said they would not do so. A total of 6.3% said they
would move to Russia, and 86.3% said they would not do that. A total of 11.2%
of respondents said they would move to Russia if they were given "$100,000 for
relocation," while 80.2% said they would not do so.

The KIIS poll was conducted by phone between April 26 and April 30. A total of
1,500 interviews were conducted.

Presidents of Moldova, Transdniestria agree to facilitate Dniester crossing
amid coronavirus pandemic

CHISINAU. June 3 (Interfax) - Moldovan President Igor Dodon and leader of the
unrecognized Transdniestrian Moldovan Republic Vadim Krasnoselsky have agreed
in a phone call to facilitate crossing of the Dniester River amid the
coronavirus pandemic.

"I have pledged that Chisinau will prevent any steps or actions that could
infringe on the rights of residents of the Transdniestrian region. Mr.
Krasnoselsky and I expressed the shared opinion that everything necessary
should be done to protect people from the virus," Dodon said on Facebook on
Wednesday.

People from populated localities in the Dubasari district, which is a part of
Moldova, but is located on the eastern bank of the Dniester River, have to
travel through the populated localities of the Transdniestrian Moldovan
Republic in order to cross the river. The Transdniestrian authorities closed
their borders, including the border with Moldova, the moment the coronavirus
state of emergency took effect.

It was agreed to facilitate traffic between the banks of the Dniester River.
"Public health is of the utmost value, and it's also necessary to help deal
with the socioeconomic consequences," Dodon said.

"During the phone call, opinions were exchanged on the Chisinau-Tiraspol
negotiations and certain results of the activity of confidence-building
working groups. It was agreed to continue the dialogue in order to solve
problems and build up confidence between people on both banks of the
Dniester," Dodon said.

The process of negotiations between Chisinau and Tiraspol was practically
frozen after the coronavirus pandemic began. Moldova accused Transdniestria of
being reluctant to cooperate, in particular, in humanitarian affairs and in
the containment of the coronavirus pandemic. Tiraspol, in turn, accused
Chisinau of creating artificial impediments to export/import operations,
including the import of medicine. One reason for these problems is the
shutdown of all Ukrainian checkpoints in the Transdniestrian section of the
Moldovan-Ukrainian border because of the pandemic. As a result, Transdniestria
has to conduct all of its trade via Moldova.

SIMFEROPOL. June 2 (Interfax) - A drunken Ukrainian serviceman has been

"The trespasser has been identified as Ukrainian Armed Forces serviceman Ye.

Traces of a struggle with unknown persons have been discovered near the
observation post. Efforts are being undertaken to find him. The relevant
materials were rapidly handed over to law enforcement authorities," the

Ukrainian serviceman arrested in Crimea for one month in illegal border
crossing case

SIMFEROPOL. June 4 (Interfax) - Simferopol's Kyivsky District Court ruled on
Wednesday to arrest for 30 days Ukrainian serviceman Yevhen Dobrynsky, a
defendant of the criminal case over the illegal crossing of the Russian state
border, an Interfax correspondent reported from the courtroom.

"Deliver a measure of restraint in the form of a 30-day arrest term on
Dobrynsky until July 1, 2020," Judge Valentina Kamynina said.

Investigators sought a term in custody for Dobrynsky, as he was trying to run
away following the detention by border guards. Meanwhile, the Ukrainian has no
lodgings in Crimea. A spokesperson of the prosecutor's office backed the plea.
Lawyers and the defendant objected.

Resident of Ukraine's Rivne Region Yevhen Dobrynsky, 28, is an officer of the
95th Airborne Assault Brigade of the Ukrainian Armed Forces, and is married
with a little child.

"I did not want to travel to Crimea, I did not seek to cross the border. I
took a walk on the dam and wanted to look at fish," the serviceman said during
the trial.

The defense team wants to appeal the first-instance court ruling in the
Crimean Supreme Court, Islyam Velilyayev, a lawyer of the Ukrainian officer,
told reporters.

Meanwhile, the Command of the Airborne Troops of the Ukrainian Armed Forces
said the Russian special service's information about the condition of
Dobrynsky during the detention is "Russia's predicted propaganda."

"The guy looks frustrated on the video [of the interrogation]. He is
pronouncing the text prepared in advance. It is not ruled out that he is under
the impact of special medications," the command of the Ukrainian Airborne
Troops added.

The United States embassy to Ukraine expressed concern by the reports about
the detention of the Ukrainian officer, American diplomats said in a brief
message on social media sites.

As reported, the Ukrainian military police said on Facebook on May 30 that "a
serviceman of the Ukrainian Armed Forces stationed at an observation post went
missing" in the vicinity of Chonhar in the Kherson region at about 5 a.m., and
said that he might be abducted, as "the traces of a struggle with unknown
persons" were allegedly discovered.

Two days later, on June 2, the Russian Federal Security Service said that a
drunken Ukrainian serviceman had been detained. A package, presumably
containing a drug was seized from Dobrynsky. A criminal inquiry was launched
against the Ukrainian for "the illegal crossing of the Russian state border."

Crimean border guards made public a video of the interrogation of the
Ukrainian detainee on Tuesday evening.

He said he had been seconded for three months to protect a railway bridge and
a dam in the area.

The serviceman said that he had a day-off on May 29, in the evening he went to
the village of Sivash to buy cigarettes and met a group of local residents at
a bus stop, they were drinking alcohol and smoking pot. These villagers
invited the serviceman to join them and gave him a package containing drugs.

After that, the young man decided to take a walk on the dam.

"Strolling on the dam, I went down to the waterline, went off the dam, and sat
on the rail track. Walking there, I noticed two armed people, I waved at them
and said, 'Hi, do not shoot, I came with peace.' I was detained," the
serviceman said.

"I was a little drunk. Local residents gave me a package, which contained
cannabis," the detainee added.

Dobrynsky also said that he had no claims to Crimean border guards.

The Armyansk, Dzhankoi, and Perekop border checkpoints are located in the
north of Crimea. Their Ukrainian counterparts are Kalanchak, Chonhar, and
Chaplynka. A small buffer zone is located between Russian and Ukrainian border
checkpoints.

Medical assistance provided to Whelan in untimely manner - U.S. embassy

MOSCOW. May 29 (Interfax) - The United States embassy to Russia has said it
believes that medical assistance was provided to Paul Whelan, who has been
charged with espionage in Russia, only when his condition became critical.

"Russian authorities waited until Paul Whelan's condition was life-threatening
to provide him medical attention. That is unacceptable and dangerous," U.S.
embassy spokesperson Rebecca Ross said on Twitter.

The U.S. repeatedly requested that an English-speaking doctor be allowed to
see Whelan, but "he's been denied necessary medical attention," Ross said.

U.S. Ambassador John Sullivan spoke to Whelan on Friday, she said. "We will be
monitoring Paul's progress closely, and we hope he will recover quickly," the
U.S. diplomat said.

Whelan's brother said earlier that Whelan had undergone surgery for a hernia.
The surgery was successful, he said.

Germany suggests waiting for invitations to G7 summit, believes Russia may
take part as guest - govt spokesperson

BERLIN. June 3 (Interfax) - Russia may well take part in a G7 summit in the
United States in 2020 as a guest, but it would be reasonable to wait for an
invitation from the U.S. before talking about this, German government
spokesperson Steffen Seibert said on Wednesday.

"The decision on when such a summit is to be held rests with the host party.
Concerning its format, guests have traditionally been invited to G7 summits.
This is always a question for the host party. But if we're talking about
changing the G7's format, such a decision must be agreed upon by all G7
members unanimously," Seibert said in response to a question from Interfax on
Wednesday.

Having guests at the summit and an expanded format are different things, he
said.

Seibert said this approach to all countries that may potentially be guests at
the summit is a matter of principle.

"The format can be changed only provided that all the G7 countries adhere to
the same position. Concerning Russia, there is a 2014 decision, when the G8
format existed, and the basis for this decision hasn't changed," Seibert said.

The 2014 decision was based on "the unlawful annexation of Crimea" by Russia,
he said.

"The chance to change this state of affairs is in the Russian leadership's
hands," Seibert said. He suggested waiting for any further announcements from
U.S. President Donald Trump.

Trump earlier described the G7 format as inefficient and announced his
intention to invite Russia, India, South Korea, and Australia to a summit to
be hosted by the U.S. in 2020.

June 2 (Interfax) - Russia may employ its nuclear deterrence capabilities in case of threats of aggression against it resulting from certain actions by potential adversaries, according to the fundamentals of Russia's state nuclear deterrence policy, which were endorsed by Russian President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday.

June 2 (Interfax) - Russia may employ its nuclear deterrence capabilities in case of threats of aggression against it resulting from certain actions by potential adversaries, according to the fundamentals of Russia's state nuclear deterrence policy, which were endorsed by Russian President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday.

The presidential decree lists the key dangers which, depending on changes in the military-political and strategic situation, may evolve into military threats (threats of aggression) to Russia and for the neutralization of which Russia shall employ its nuclear deterrence capabilities.

Among these dangers is "the buildup by a potential adversary of conventional armed forces, including systems of nuclear weapons delivery, in territories neighboring the Russian Federation and its allies and in adjacent sea areas," the decree published on the official online database for legal information says.

"The deployment by states viewing the Russian Federation as a potential adversary of missile defense systems and means, medium-range and shorter- ranger cruise and ballistic missiles, precision-guided non-nuclear and hypersonic weapons, unmanned combat aerial vehicles, and directed-energy weapons" also constitutes a precondition for Russia to employ its nuclear deterrence capabilities, according to the document.

The other dangers that may prompt Russia to use its nuclear deterrence capabilities include "the development of missile defense and attack systems and their deployment to outer space," "the possession by states of nuclear weapons and (or) other types of weapons of mass destruction that may be used against the Russian Federation and (or) its allies, as well as delivery systems for such types of weapons," the uncontrollable proliferation of nuclear weapons and their delivery systems, technology and equipment for their manufacture, and "the deployment of nuclear weapons and systems for their delivery to the territories of non-nuclear states."

"In commemoration of the 75th anniversary of the Victory in the Great Patriotic War of 1941-1945 and the Victory Parade of June 24, 1945, as a gesture of gratitude to the conquerors of the Nazi invaders from their descendants, paying a tribute to the great valor, heroism and selflessness of the war veterans, I decree holding military parades on Red Square in Moscow and in other cities of the Russian Federation at 10 a.m. local time on June 24, 2020, engaging weapons and military hardware and using the Victory Banner as an official symbol of the Soviet people's Victory in the Great Patriotic War, according to the established procedure," the document says.

title: Interfax Russia & CIS Military Weekly
html:
Corridors of Power

Too early to talk about agenda of next NATO-Russia Council meeting - Russian Foreign Ministry

MOSCOW. May 29 (Interfax) - The next meeting of the NATO-Russia Council has not yet been decided on, and it is too early to talk about the agenda for the event, Russian Foreign Ministry Department of European Cooperation Director Nikolai Kobrinets told Interfax.

"The issue of holding the next meeting of the NATO-Russia Council has not been decided yet. Therefore, it's too early to talk about the agenda for the aforementioned event," Kobrinets said, in answer to a question from Interfax as to whether a meeting of the NATO-Russia Council may take place soon.

Answering a question whether the withdrawal of the United States from the Treaty on Open Skies will be brought up at the meeting of the council, Kobrinets said, "We're using all available opportunities to build an equal dialogue with the alliance, aimed at increasing transparency and deescalating tensions in Europe. Senior Foreign Ministry officials have repeatedly voiced Russia's stance on Washington's decision to unilaterally withdraw from the Treaty on Open Skies."

Corridors of Power

Expansion of Russian military bases in Syria to broaden their functions, improve security - State Duma member

MOSCOW. May 29 (Interfax) - The planned expansion of Hmeimim and Tartus, Russian military bases in Syria, will improve their functionality and security, Russian State Duma Defense Committee Deputy Chairman Yury Shvytkin told Interfax.

"The functionality that Tartus has now is rather limited. It has been proposed turning it into a proper naval base, which would have a broader spectrum of functions in regard to servicing ships in the Mediterranean Sea, repairing them, and naturally, carrying out strikes on terrorists, if necessary," Shvytkin said on Friday.

He went on to comment on the upcoming talks with Syria about transferring additional immovable property and areas at sea to Russian military forces under an agreement on the deployment of a Russian aviation group.

Regarding the Hmeimim base, Shvytkin said that he has visited it. "I can tell you that the civil and the military airports as such are located very close to each other. Of course, there's a need to separate them," he said.

"There is also a need to ensure the security of the military personnel and equipment stationed at the Hmeimim base on distant approaches to the Hmeimim base," Shvytkin said.

"The expansion will help our taskforce more effectively accomplish the tasks set for it in the Syrian Arab Republic and, of course, defend the personnel and armored vehicles at this base," he said.

Corridors of Power

Whelan getting full hospital assistance after hernia surgery - Russian Foreign Ministry

MOSCOW. May 29 (Interfax) - Paul Whelan, who is accused of espionage in Russia, is getting all necessary hospital assistance after a simple hernia surgery, which he previously refused to undergo, the Russian Foreign Ministry said.

Late at night on May 27, Whelan reached out to the administration of the Lefortovo detention facility, complaining about a substantial deterioration of his health due to an aggravation of a medical condition he had. He was sent to the Sklifosovsky Institute of Emergency Care immediately after being examined by doctors of a medical unit, the Foreign Ministry said in a statement on Friday.

"In the early morning of May 28, Whelan was operated on. As we said earlier, he previously refused to undergo this simple surgical intervention. He was discharged from hospital and taken back to the detention center on May 29. Paul Whelan is getting all quality curative care in the facility where he is being held," the ministry said.

Corridors of Power

Putin approves Russia's counter-extremism strategy

MOSCOW. May 29 (Interfax) - Russian President Vladimir Putin has approved a national strategy for countering extremism for the period to 2025.

The relevant decree was published on the official web portal for legal information.

The current trend is toward further radicalization among certain groups of population and the rise of external and domestic extremist threats, the document said.

The strategy defines external extremist threats as "a number of states' supporting and encouraging destructive activities by foreign or international nongovernmental organizations, aimed at socio-political and socio-economic destabilization in Russia, breaking the unity and territorial integrity of Russia, including the instigation of 'color revolutions,' and at destroying the traditional Russian spiritual and moral values."

Aiding international extremist and terrorist organizations, in particular by propagating the extremist ideology and radicalism within society, also qualifies as an external extremist threat.

"Internal extremist threats are attempts by nationalist, radical nongovernmental, religious, ethnic and other organizations and groups and certain individuals to carry out extremist activities to attain their own goals," the strategy says.

Such activities involve promoting violence, inciting, recruiting or otherwise engaging Russians and foreigners in Russia in extremist and other unlawful activity, and forming closed ethnic and religious enclaves.

Some states are using extremism as a means to geopolitical ends such as violating the territorial integrity of, or causing civil wars and "color revolutions" in other states - their geopolitical adversaries, the document said. "The real threat is posed by the recent rise in instances of intentional distortion of history, the revival of the ideas of nationalism and fascism in foreign states," the strategy says.

Information and telecommunications networks including the internet have become a major recruitment tool used by extremist organizations. "Engaging various groups of population to participate in unpermitted public gatherings (including protests), which are deliberately transformed into mass disturbances, is increasingly becoming a preferred method of causing socio-political and socio-economic destabilization in Russia," the strategy says.

Corridors of Power

Putin signs decree on holding Victory Parade on June 24, declares it non-working day - Kremlin

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Russian President Vladimir Putin has signed a decree on holding military parades and artillery firework displays in commemoration of the 75th anniversary of the Victory in the Great Patriotic War of 1941-1945 and the Victory Parade of June 24, 1945, the Kremlin press service said.

"In commemoration of the 75th anniversary of the Victory in the Great Patriotic War of 1941-1945 and the Victory Parade of June 24, 1945, as a gesture of gratitude to the conquerors of the Nazi invaders from their descendants, paying a tribute to the great valor, heroism and selflessness of the war veterans, I decree holding military parades on Red Square in Moscow and in other cities of the Russian Federation at 10 a.m. local time on June 24, 2020, engaging weapons and military hardware and using the Victory Banner as an official symbol of the Soviet people's Victory in the Great Patriotic War, according to the established procedure," the document says.

The decree also orders conducting artillery firework displays in Moscow and some other cities across Russia at 10:00 p.m. local time on June 24.

The document declares June 24 a paid non-working day.

The decree takes effect on the day of its signature.

Corridors of Power

U.S. position on Open Skies treaty, New START would ruin int'l security architecture - Medvedev

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The United States' withdrawal from the Treaty on Open Skies and Washington's position on the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (New START) are destroying the architecture of international security, Dmitry Medvedev, Deputy Chairman of the Russian Security Council, said.

"The White House's position on these documents is leading to the destruction of the architecture of international security and will have serious consequences," Medvedev wrote on his Vk page.

He was among other Security Council permanent members who met with the president earlier on Saturday to work out Russia's definitive position on the U.S. withdrawal from the Open Skies treaty and the situation around New START.

Corridors of Power

Russian Foreign Ministry denies U.S. claims of sending Libya false Russian-printed dinars seized in Malta

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The Russian Foreign Ministry has denied a claim by the United States Department of State regarding the confiscation in Malta of an equivalent of $1.1 billion of "counterfeit" Libyan dinars printed by the Russian joint stock company Goznak for the eastern Libyan government.

"The contract to print Libyan dinars was signed in 2015 between Goznak and the head of Libya's Central Bank approved by the Libyan House of Representatives (parliament). The Libyan side made the required prepayment. In accordance with its contractual obligations, the Russian organization sent the Central Bank in Tobruk a shipment with the printed Libyan banknotes. We are working on the premise that said money is needed to support the stable functioning of the entire Libyan economy," the Russian Foreign Ministry said in a statement on Saturday.

Because of the current duopoly in Libya, it has two central banks: one is in Tripoli, the seat of the internationally recognized government of national accord led by Fayez al-Sarraj, and the other is in Benghazi, whose governor was appointed by an elected parliament, the House of Representative, and thus possesses the necessary international legitimacy, the ministry said.

"Thus, it is not the Libyan dinars but U.S. claims that are false," the statement said.

Corridors of Power

UN panel of experts on Libya found no sanctions breach in shipment of banknotes to the country - Goznak

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The use of the term "false" toward the banknotes seized in Malta, intended for the Central Bank of Libya, is unsubstantiated and unlawful, the Russian joint stock company Goznak, which printed them, said.

"The shipment of the print run in question was a subject of examination by the UN Security Council panel of experts ono Libya, which found no violation of the sanctions against this country in accordance with the UN Resolution No. 2259 (2019), which in turn was reflected in the panel's December 2019 report. Goznak fulfilled all of its obligations under the aforesaid contract," the company said.

"The banknotes made for this shipment are a modified series of previous banknotes and are visually different from them. Samples of these banknotes were approved by Libyan Central Bank representatives in an established manner; therefore the application of the term 'false' toward these banknotes is unsubstantiated and unlawful," Goznak said.

"As is known, the Central Bank of Libya has two offices, in Tripoli and in Tobruk. The contract under which the batch of banknotes in question was manufactured, was concluded by Goznak with the Central Bank of Libya office in Tobruk," the company said.

"The commissioning of banknotes from Goznak was approved by the board of directors of the Central Bank of Libya as far back as 2015. The right of the Central Bank of Libya in Tobruk to conclude this kind of contract was, in 2016, reaffirmed by a resolution of the Government of National Accord (Tripoli). Despite all the differences between the two sides, this decision was not canceled and is valid to this day. The relevant contract with our company was signed by a person vested with all necessary powers to that end," the company said.

"In violation of the norms of international law, in September of 2019 the Malta Customs Authority detained containers with the banknotes belonging to the Central Bank of Libya. Goznak, along with the customer, have repeatedly sought to obtain explanations from Maltese authorities. For several months Maltese customs agencies were providing no explanations over the seizure of the banknotes, and only in May 2020 did they react with a statement whose contents substantially misrepresents the actual circumstances surrounding the relationship between Goznak and the Central Bank of Libya.

"We recommend that all other questions regarding the batch of banknotes in question should be referred to their issuer, the Central Bank of Libya located in Tobruk," Goznak said.

Earlier on Saturday, the Russian Foreign Ministry denied a claim by the United States Department of State about the batch of Libyan dinars, printed by Goznak for the eastern Libyan government and seized in Malta, being fake.

Corridors of Power

Russian envoy denies Moscow's involvement in violent protests in U.S.

BRUSSELS. June 1 (Interfax) - Russian Permanent Representative to International Organizations in Vienna Mikhail Ulyanov has called the allegations of Moscow's involvement in the wave of protests against the killing of unarmed African American George Floyd by the police in the United States unbelievable.

Susan Rice, former national security advisor in the Barack Obama administration, said earlier she suspected Russia of being behind the violent protests in the United States.

Rice said on CNN that both peaceful protesters and extremists were participating in the demonstrations. "I would not be surprised to learn that they have fomented some of these extremists on both sides using social media," Rice said.

"Unbelievable! But she is not kidding. She is absolutely serious. Demonisation of Russians or brainwashing? Maybe both?" Ulyanov said on Twitter.

"As expected, the U.S. media has started speculating on the subject of Russia being behind the riots in the United States. That's an illustrative example of crisis phenomena in U.S. society. Instead of looking into the root of their problems, they are looking for external 'culprits'," the diplomat said.

Flyod was detained by the Minneapolis police on May 25. An officer pressed down his neck with a knee in the course of detention. Floyd died in a hospital's ICU and a video of his detention was released online.

Corridors of Power

Allegations on Moscow's possible role in U.S. protests are 'erroneous insinuations' - Kremlin

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The remarks by Susan Rice, former national security advisor to United States President Barack Obama, suggesting that Moscow might be behind the ongoing violent protests in the U.S. are erroneous insinuations, which cannot reflect Washington's official views, Russian presidential press secretary Dmitry Peskov said.

"First, we certainly are following what's happening in the U.S. very closely, but everything that's happening there is the internal affair of that country. We've never meddled in American affairs, and we aren't going to meddle now, either," Peskov told journalists on Monday, when asked to comment on Rice's remarks.

"Any insinuations, like the ones you've just mentioned, are of course absolutely wrong and erroneous. And as far as we understand, such insinuations cannot reflect Washington's official standpoint in any way," he said.

Corridors of Power

Allegations of Russia's involvement in violent protests in U.S. are fake - Russian Foreign Ministry

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The Russian Foreign Ministry has described allegations of Russia's involvement in violent protests in the United States, which were triggered by the death of an African American man, George Floyd, at the hands of the police, as propaganda and fake.

Susan Rice, former national security advisor in the Barack Obama administration, said earlier she suspected Russia of being behind the violent protests in the United States.

"In the past, your fellow party members made a fatal mistake: they created a very silly concept suggesting that Russia should be blamed for everything you don't like. Hillary Clinton and the entire Obama team convinced themselves and tried to convince the world that domestic U.S. problems are created and worsened by someone 'from the outside,' i.e., Russia," Russian Foreign Ministry spokesperson Maria Zakharova said on Facebook.

"You're trying to make the same mistake by resorting, together with journalists from CNN, to the dirty methods of manipulating information: there are fake statements and zero facts to support them. Your interview with CNN is the actual propaganda," Zakharova said.

Floyd was detained by the Minneapolis police on May 25. An officer pressed his knee into Floyd's neck while detaining him. Floyd later died in a hospital's ICU, and a video of his detention was released online.

Corridors of Power

No positive dynamics in summit-level dialogue with Ukraine, Georgia - Peskov

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - For now, the Kremlin cannot affirm positive dynamics in summit-level dialogue with Ukraine and Georgia, Russian presidential press secretary Dmitry Peskov said.

"As for the leadership of those countries, unfortunately, for now, despite the existence of certain contacts, we cannot boast of positive dynamics in the summit-level dialogue," Peskov said in an interview with the TV program "Moscow. Kremlin. Putin," aired on the Rossiya 24 (VGTRK) television channel.

He thus answered a question as to why Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky was not invited to attend the Victory Parade in Moscow and whether this decision could have been caused by his comments on WWII.

"First and foremost, the dynamics depend on how the heads of state keep their promises and fulfill their obligations," Peskov said.

Peskov said that the Russian president congratulates the peoples of Ukraine and Georgia on Victory Day every year, "because these are fraternal peoples, who share deep, historical roots with us, and because Putin has a profound and sincere respect for these peoples."

Corridors of Power

Armenian PM invited to Moscow to attend Victory Parade on June 24

YEREVAN. June 1 (Interfax) - Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan has received an invitation from Russia to come to Moscow to attend a military parade in commemoration of the 75th anniversary of the victory in the Great Patriotic War, which is planned for June 24, the Armenian government press service said.

Pashinyan thanked Russian President Vladimir Putin for the invitation in a telephone call on Monday, the press service said.

"Nikol Pashinyan said he hopes he will recover by this date and will be able to attend all events being planned in the context of the 75th anniversary of Victory," it said.

Putin wished Pashinyan a happy birthday and the soonest possible recovery.

Pashinyan announced earlier on Monday that he and his family have been diagnosed with the new coronavirus.

Corridors of Power

Russia tells Czech ambassador it is perplexed by Prague delaying bilateral consultations - Russian Foreign Ministry

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Czech Ambassador in Moscow Vitezslav Pivonka has been summoned to the Russian Foreign Ministry over Prague's postponement of consultations on key bilateral issues, the Russian Foreign Ministry said.

"Ambassador of the Czech Republic to the Russian Federation Vitezslav Pivonka was invited to the Russian Foreign Ministry on June 1. During a conversation with First Deputy Foreign Minister of the Russian Federation Vladimir Titov, the Czech diplomat was informed that Russia is perplexed by Prague delaying consultations on key issues of Russian-Czech relations on the basis of the August 26, 1993 Treaty on Friendly Relations and Cooperation between the Russian Federation and the Czech Republic," the Foreign Ministry said in a statement published on its website.

It was also noted at the meeting that the atmosphere accompanying bilateral relations has considerably worsened recently, and a large number of problems, which emerged not through Russia's fault, have accumulated.

"Russia is ready for dialogue on this matter, but continuing destructive steps on the part of Czech authorities raise serious doubts about their willingness to improve the situation. It was stressed that we will plan further steps in relations with the Czech Republic depending on its reaction to our demarche," the ministry said.

Corridors of Power

Lavrov, Guterres discuss Syria, Libya, Covid-19 pandemic in phone call

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and United Nations Secretary General Antonio Guterres discussed the situation in Libya, the Syrian crisis, and the coronavirus pandemic, including in the context of the World Health Organization's (WHO) role in tackling this problem, in a telephone call, the Russian Foreign Ministry said on Monday.

"During the conversation, the participants gave particular attention to the problem of the Syrian and Libyan settlement processes with a focus on individual aspects of the UN's activities on these tracks, as well as to the World Health Organization's work to respond to the consequences of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic," the ministry said in a statement published on its website.

"The Russian side noted the priority of appointing the head of the UN mission in Libya as soon as possible amid the continuing degradation of the situation in this country," it said.

In addition, Lavrov and Guterres "held an extensive exchange of opinions on the situation "on the ground" in Syria, including Russia and Turkey's efforts to stabilize the situation and maintain the ceasefire in the Idlib de-escalation area within the framework of the Additional Protocol dated March 5 of this year," the ministry said.

"They also noted the threat of terrorists stepping up their activities in Syria amid the coronavirus pandemic and stressed the need to ensure lasting security and stability in the country on the basis of restoring its sovereignty and territorial integrity," it said.

"The parties also discussed in detail the tasks of intensifying the delivery of humanitarian aid to Syrians in need across the country's territory without any discrimination, politicization, and preliminary conditions," the ministry said.

"Lavrov reaffirmed Russia's support for the work of the UN and its specialized institutions aimed at coordinating the member countries' efforts to overcome the Covid-19 pandemic and its socioeconomic aftermath," it said.

"The sides also discussed ways to increase the effectiveness of global cooperation in this field and broaden multilateral interaction on the platform of this global organization," the ministry said.

Corridors of Power

Putin, Trump discuss by phone G7 summit, Covid-19, oil market

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Russian President Vladimir Putin and U.S. President Donald Trump have discussed in a telephone call the situation surrounding Covid-19, the Crew Dragon spacecraft launch, the G7 summit, as well as the situation on the oil market, the Kremlin press service said.

"The parties have exchanged views on the measures taken in both countries to counter coronavirus. Vladimir Putin expressed gratitude for the delivery of U.S. ventilators to Russia," the press service said.

Putin congratulated his U.S. counterpart "on the successful launch of the Crew Dragon crewed spacecraft, which took the U.S. astronauts to the International Space Station, on May 30," it said. "Shared commitment to the development of mutually beneficial cooperation in the field of space was reiterated," the press service said.

The leaders of the two countries also addressed the situation on the global oil market in the context of the implementation of the OPEC+ deal. "It was stated that this multilateral agreement, reached with active support of the presidents of Russia and the U.S., is leading to the gradual resumption of the demand for oil and stabilization of prices," the Kremlin press service said.

"Donald Trump has informed [Putin] of his idea of holding the Group of Seven summit and possibly inviting the leaders of Russia, Australia, India, and South Korea," it said.

"The importance of intensifying the Russian-U.S. dialogue on strategic stability and confidence-building measures in the military sector was noted," the press service said.

During the telephone call, the leaders agreed on the continuation of contacts at various levels.

"The conversation was constructive, business-like and meaningful," the press service said.

The telephone call took place at the initiative of the U.S. side, it said.

Corridors of Power

No evidence to uphold UN monitors' claim that Taliban maintaining ties with al-Qaeda - Russian diplomat

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Moscow sees no evidence to uphold the assertions by UN monitors that the Taliban (banned in Russia) is continuing to maintain ties with the terrorist group al-Qaeda (banned in Russia) in Afghanistan, even despite its obligation not to do so under its agreement with the United States, Russian presidential envoy for Afghanistan and Director of the Foreign Ministry's Second Asian Department Zamir Kabulov said when commenting on a recent report by a UN monitoring team.

"Not everything is so obvious about this report; there's no evidence presented in it, only a lot of inference," Kabulov said in an interview with Interfax.

Members of the UN Analytical Support and Sanctions Monitoring Team earlier issued a report alleging that the Taliban is continuing to maintain close communication with al-Qaeda, despite its obligation to sever any links with it, as stipulated by its agreement with the U.S.

"Concerns about al-Qaeda are, so to speak, a purely American thing," Kabulov said.

"The Americans, I mean those who professionally deal with the situation in Afghanistan, are perfectly aware that al-Qaeda is now a small international terrorist group with no significant combat capability," he said.

Al-Qaeda is of symbolic significance for Americans, as U.S. forces were sent to Afghanistan to fight this particular group, Kabulov said. "And they just have to heighten al-Qaeda's profile, so as to rationalize their foreign political ideology," he said.

Corridors of Power

Peskov on Donetsk's plan to hold victory parade: This is common history bringing our peoples together

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Donetsk's plans to hold a military parade commemorating the 75th anniversary of the Soviet Union's victory in the Great Patriotic War show that the people there venerate common history, Russian presidential press secretary Dmitry Peskov said.

"This could well be timed to coincide with the organization of a parade in Moscow. The holding of a parade itself in commemoration of the remarkable date of the 75th anniversary of the victory in the Great Patriotic War - and it's a truly remarkable date for our peoples, it is common history that brings our peoples together - this is something of which we can and should be proud," Peskov told journalists on Tuesday.

Asked to clarify which peoples he was talking about, Peskov said, "I'm talking about our common nation, the victorious nation that conquered the Nazis and saved Europe from the Nazis."

Head of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) Denis Pushilin said earlier that Donetsk will hold a military parade on June 24 in commemoration of the 75th anniversary of the victory in the 1941-1945 war.

Corridors of Power

Peskov says it's wrong to compare U.S. events with Russian issues

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - The protests sparked by the death of an African American man named George Floyd as a result of his detention in the United States have nothing in common with the Russian agenda, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said.

"I don't agree with your opinion that issues which are high on the U.S. public agenda are somehow related to our agenda. We have our own agenda, and thank God, what's going on in America isn't happening here," Peskov told journalists in response to a question whether the Kremlin believes it will be necessary to look into police conduct in the light of the events in the U.S.

When commenting on reports that Yekaterinburg police shot and killed a man suspected of stealing four rolls of wallpaper, Peskov said, "Regretfully, you and I are unaware of the details of the Yekaterinburg incident."

"You and I do not know for sure what happened there. It would be wrong to discuss or comment on the issue without this knowledge," he said.

Corridors of Power

Putin, Trump did not discuss unrest in U.S. - Peskov

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - The current unrest in the United States, which was triggered by the death of an African American man named George Floyd, was not discussed in the phone call between Russian President Vladimir Putin and his U.S. counterpart Donald Trump on Monday, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told the press on Tuesday.

"No. That's not an issue of Russian-U.S. bilateral relations," Peskov said in response to the relevant question.

If Russians residing in the United States need assistance or protection, they will be provided with such, he said.

"There are Russian diplomatic missions and representative offices in the United States. Of course, if citizens need protection, they'll receive it," Peskov said.

Moscow so far not invited to conversation among Normandy-format FMs - source

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Russia's nuclear deterrence policy is of a defensive nature, and using nuclear weapons is a last resort, according to the fundamentals of Russia's nuclear deterrence policy, which have been approved by an executive order by Russian President Vladimir Putin.

"State policy in the field of nuclear deterrence has a defensive nature; it aims to maintain the potential of nuclear forces at a level sufficient for nuclear deterrence and which guarantees the sovereignty and territorial integrity of the nation," the document says.

Russia publishes list of key dangers due to which nuclear deterrence may be used

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Russia may employ its nuclear deterrence capabilities in case of threats of aggression against it resulting from certain actions by potential adversaries, according to the fundamentals of Russia's state nuclear deterrence policy, which were endorsed by Russian President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday.

The presidential decree lists the key dangers which, depending on changes in the military-political and strategic situation, may evolve into military threats (threats of aggression) to Russia and for the neutralization of which Russia shall employ its nuclear deterrence capabilities.

Among these dangers is "the buildup by a potential adversary of conventional armed forces, including systems of nuclear weapons delivery, in territories neighboring the Russian Federation and its allies and in adjacent sea areas," the decree published on the official online database for legal information says.

"The deployment by states viewing the Russian Federation as a potential adversary of missile defense systems and means, medium-range and shorter-ranger cruise and ballistic missiles, precision-guided non-nuclear and hypersonic weapons, unmanned combat aerial vehicles, and directed-energy weapons" also constitutes a precondition for Russia to employ its nuclear deterrence capabilities, according to the document.

The other dangers that may prompt Russia to use its nuclear deterrence capabilities include "the development of missile defense and attack systems and their deployment to outer space," "the possession by states of nuclear weapons and (or) other types of weapons of mass destruction that may be used against the Russian Federation and (or) its allies, as well as delivery systems for such types of weapons," the uncontrollable proliferation of nuclear weapons and their delivery systems, technology and equipment for their manufacture, and "the deployment of nuclear weapons and systems for their delivery to the territories of non-nuclear states."

Russia shall employ its nuclear deterrence capabilities with regard to individual states and military coalitions (blocs, alliances) that view Russia as a potential adversary and possess nuclear weapons and (or) other types of weapons of mass destruction or substantial conventional force capabilities, it says.

"In employing its nuclear deterrence capabilities, the Russian Federation shall take into account potential adversary's deployment of offensive weapons to the territories of other states (cruise and ballistic missiles, hypersonic aerial vehicles, or unmanned combat aerial vehicles), directed-energy weapons, missile defense and early warning systems, nuclear weapons and (or) other types of weapons of mass destruction, which may be used against the Russian Federation and (or) its allies," the document says.

Additionally, the Russian Security Council coordinates the activity of federal executive bodies, which implement presidential orders pertaining to nuclear deterrence, the document says.

The Russian Defense Ministry operates via the General Staff "to ensure direct planning and implementation of organizational and military measures in the field of nuclear deterrence," it says.

Decisions on Russia's use of nuclear arms rest with president - document

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Decisions on the use of nuclear weapons by Russia rest with the president, according to the fundamentals of Russia's state nuclear deterrence policy endorsed by Russian President Vladimir Putin.

The presidential decree endorsing the policy has been published on the official online database for legal information.

"Decisions on the use of nuclear weapons shall be made by the president of the Russian Federation," the document says.

The document outlines a number of preconditions for the possible use of nuclear weapons.

In particular, such a decision may be made if Russia receives accurate information on the launch of ballistic missiles attacking the territories of Russia or its allies.

These preconditions also include "the use by an adversary of nuclear weapons or other types of weapons of mass destruction on the territories of Russia or its allies" and "an impact by an adversary on critically important state or military sites of the Russian Federation, whose disablement would disrupt the retaliatory effects of its nuclear forces."

Aggression against Russia with the use of conventional weapons that could jeopardize the very existence of the state may also serve as valid grounds for Russia to use nuclear weapons, the document says.

"If necessary, the president of the Russian Federation may inform the military-political leadership of other countries and international organizations of Russia's preparedness to use nuclear weapons, or of the decision to use nuclear weapons, or of the fact of their use," it says.

Russia reserves the right to use nuclear weapons "in retaliation for the use of nuclear and other types of weapons of mass destruction against itself and its allies, as well as in the event of aggression against the Russian Federation with the use of conventional weapons, if this threatens the very existence of the state," the document says.

Despite the spread of the new coronavirus infection around the world, there has been a considerable increase in NATO combat training events that are clearly anti-Russian," Rudskoi told reporters on Monday.

The largest exercise was the Defender Europe 2020 exercise, in which the transfer of a U.S. contingent from the U.S. to Europe was envisaged, he said.

"The U.S. planned to involve in the exercise more than 28,000 troops, 287 tanks, 449 armored vehicles, and 95 helicopters. Another 17 countries planned to form their contingents and involve five multinational units from SHAPE [Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe]," Rudskoi said.

"This exercise was clearly anti-Russian," as practically all combat training events were conducted on firing ranges near the Russian border, and facilities on the territory of Russia were regarded as probable targets, he said.

"For example, landing operations in the Baltics and the Caucasus were expected to be held before May 9 in these events. That didn't happen only due to quarantine," Rudskoi said.

Attempts were made during the preparations for Defender Europe 2020 to bypass the provisions of the Vienna document by dividing the large-scale training into smaller parts and involving neutral states in the maneuvers," he said.

Chief of the General Staff of the Russian Armed Forces Valery Gerasimov many times brought up this issue at talks last year and this year with NATO's command in Europe, with former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Joseph Dunford, current Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Mark Milley, and NATO Military Committee Chairman Air Chief Marshal Stuart Peach, Rudskoi said.

At a meeting with NATO's Supreme Allied Commander in Europe Gen. Tod Wolters in February this year, Russia once again reminded the alliance of its initiative to transfer districts hosting large-scale operative and combat training exercises deep inside the territory of border countries.

"All our suggestions aimed at reducing tensions and averting incidents were outlined in Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov's letter to NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg. However, in actual fact, our suggestions were ignored," Rudskoi said.

Sedov, Pallada sailing ships call on Vladivostok in the end of round-the-world voyage

VLADIVOSTOK. June 3 (Interfax) - The Pallada and Sedov sailing ships of the Federal Agency for Fishery, which had been on a round-the-world voyage commemorating the 75th anniversary of the victory in the Great Patriotic War and the 200th anniversary of the discovery of Antarctica, arrived in Vladivostok on Wednesday, an Interfax correspondent reported from the location.

The welcome ceremony for the Pallada was held at Pier 33 of Korabelnaya Embankment, and the Sedov stayed anchored in the port's roadsteads for now.

The Pallada crew was presented with a round loaf of bread and a traditional roasted piglet. The sailors were congratulated by Far Eastern State Technical Fisheries University Rector Oleg Shcheka, who decorated Pallada captain Nikolai Zorchenko and several crewmembers with medals on the occasion of the completion of the round-the-world voyage.

"We saw you off on the round-the-world voyage from the same pier 216 days ago. You fully accomplished your mission. We are proud that you have demonstrated a high degree of professionalism and skills during this voyage. The second part of the voyage, when the coronavirus infection started spreading throughout the world and you had to skip a number of ports, was particularly difficult for you and us, who were waiting for you on the ground. You coped with every difficulty and once again proved to the entire world that Russian sailors are the world's best," the rector said.

As reported earlier, the unique round-the-world expedition of sailing ships of the Federal Agency for Fishery, Sails of Peace was dedicated to the 200th anniversary of the discovery of Antarctica by Russian sailors and the 75th anniversary of the victory in the Great Patriotic War.

The Pallada departed from Vladivostok on November 1, 2019. The Sedov and Kruzenshtern barques left Kaliningrad on December 8, 2019. The three sailing ships of the Federal Agency for Fishery had their first-ever rendezvous off the Falkland Islands (Malvinas) and took part in the joint 200-mile regatta.

About 700 cadets of marine colleges and higher educational establishments of the Federal Agency for Fishery had their internship with the ships' crews.

The Pallada covered a distance of over 26,000 nautical miles, including more than 6,500 using the sails only. It crossed the Pacific, Atlantic and Indian oceans, twice crossed the equator, and called on ports Apia (Samoa), Papeete (Tahiti), Valparaiso (Chile), Ushuaia (Argentina), Cape Town (South Africa) and Singapore.

The Sedov crossed the Baltic and North seas and the Atlantic and Indian oceans. It covered a distance of about 20,000 nautical miles and called on seven foreign ports. The Sedov will return to its home port, Kaliningrad, in October.

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Denis Konovalov, a former policeman who earlier confessed to planting narcotic drugs on journalist Ivan Golunov, said another policeman, Akbar Sergaliyev, was aware of his actions on falsifying evidence, a source familiar with some details of the investigation said.

"Konovalov said while being questioned face-to-face with Sergaliyev that the latter was aware that their superior, Igor Lyakhovets, had instructed him to back up the results of the search and investigative procedures," the source told Interfax on Friday.

Golunov was questioned face-to-face with Sergaliyev as part of the investigation on Friday, he said.

The Basmanny District Court ruled on January 30 to arrest Igor Lyakhovets, a senior official from the drug control division of the police department for Moscow's Western Administrative District, as well as four of his former subordinates, i.e. Denis Konovalov, Roman Feofanov, Akbar Sergaliyev, and Maxim Umetbayev, who were involved in detaining Golunov in June 2019.

The police officials are charged with abuse of office, falsification of evidence, and illegal drug trafficking. Konovalov was later granted house arrest at the investigation's request.

Golunov was detained on June 6, 2019, and charged with intent to deal drugs. The criminal charges were dropped on June 11, due to a public outcry.

The five police officials involved in detaining Golunov and chief of the police department for Moscow's Western Administrative District Andrei Puchkov were discharged from police at about the same time.

It emerged on December 19, 2019 that a criminal case had been opened into Golunov's detention on a count of abuse of office by police officials. Golunov said in February that he had received apologies for his wrongful prosecution from the prosecutor's office for Moscow's Western Administrative District.

Group of FSB officers to be subpoenaed to come to court as part of Set case

ST. PETERSBURG. June 1 (Interfax) - The 2nd Western Military District Court has ruled partly in favor of a request filed by defendant Viktor Filinkov's legal team to subpoena the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) officers who detained Filinkov for questioning at its visiting session in St. Petersburg as part of the trial of the Set terrorist organization (banned in Russia).

"The request shall be partly granted [...] [FSB officers] Belyayev, Tokarev, Bondarev, and Shepelev shall be subpoenaed to appear in court as witnesses," Judge Roman Muranov said on Monday, adding that "the court will take all necessary measures to ensure this interrogation," scheduled for Tuesday.

The FSB officers took part in Filinkov's detention and helped draw up relevant investigative documents.

A lawyer for another defendant, Vitaly Cherkasov, also requested an interview from officers from FSB's Penza branch, but the court dismissed the request.

Filinkov said in court earlier that FSB officers subjected him to physical violence after detaining him and forced him to learn his confession by heart. Linguistic experts, in turn, concluded that fragments of the minutes of the testimony given by Filinkov and Ilya Shakursky, who was identified during the trial as one of the Set organization's leaders and was convicted as part of the same case in Penza, are identical and were most likely compiled by one and the same person.

Filinkov, 25, and Yury Boyarshinov, 27, are on trial in St. Petersburg in the Set case. Filinkov has not admitted guilt. He told the court that he confessed under torture. Boyarshinov has agreed with the charge.

There are 11 defendants from Penza, St. Petersburg, and Moscow in the Set case, which Russia's Federal Security Service has been investigating since fall 2017. According to the FSB, young anarchists set up a group to plot terror attacks during the presidential election and the FIFA World Cup, as well as to destabilize Russia.

On February 10, during a visiting session in Penza, the Volga District Military Court sentenced seven defendants to six to 18 years in prison. The defendants pleaded not guilty and said they earlier confessed under torture.

The coronavirus test of Feofanov himself was not ready yet, the lawyer said.

The court had also ruled on Monday to extend the duration of house arrest of Denis Konovalov, another policeman implicated in the case.

As reported, during face-to-face interrogations Konovalov admitted his guilt and testified against his chief Igor Lyakhovets, who, according to investigators, is a plotter of the crime. The former policeman also testified against another fellow police officer Akbar Sergaliyev last week, an informed source told Interfax.

Golunov was detained on June 6, 2019, and was charged with attempting to sell drugs. The criminal charges against the journalist were dropped on June 11, 2019, amid a wide public campaign in support of him. Golunov said the drugs had been planted on him and assumed that the attempt to implicate him in a crime was prompted by his journalistic investigation related to the funeral business that he had been working on before his detention.

The Basmanny District Court ruled on January 30 to arrest Igor Lyakhovets, a senior official from the drug control division of the police department for Moscow's Western Administrative District, as well as four of his former subordinates, i.e. Denis Konovalov, Roman Feofanov, Akbar Sergaliyev, and Maxim Umetbayev, who were involved in detaining Golunov in June 2019. The investigation concluded that the policemen, acting on Lyakhovets's orders, procured the drugs and planted them on the journalist to implicate him in the crime.

The police officials are currently charged with abuse of office combined with violence, the use of special means and causing grave consequences, as well as falsification of evidence, and illegal drug trafficking on a large scale.

Law Enforcement

Dozens of thousands of unjustly convicted people in Russia, up to 1,000 political prisoners - human rights center

MOSCOW. June 3 (Interfax) - The human rights center Memorial has estimated the number of unjustly convicted people in Russia at dozens of thousands and the number of political prisoners at 2-3 times more than the 300 people Memorial knows of.

"The understanding of the state of the Russian law enforcement and judicial system makes it possible to believe it is probable that the number of innocent people whose guilt was not proven in accordance with the procedures established by the law in Russia is at least in the dozens of thousands. Such estimations are given by human rights experts and victims of this system, who had to personally experience it," Memorial told Interfax on Tuesday.

Moscow Memorial board member Sergey Davidis told the agency regarding the number of political prisoners, in other words, people prosecuted for political reasons, that "bearing in mind the number of existing cases which we know of and believe to have indications of political motivation and illegal prosecution in them, but which we could not investigate properly, I think the total number of political prisoners is 2-3 times more than the 314 people who are currently on our lists."

The number of known political prisoners has increased more than six times since 2015.

The Memorial report on the situation with politically motivated prosecutions states that "an overwhelming majority of political prisoners are people imprisoned in connection with the exercise of the right to freedom of religion and religious affiliation."

In regard of the prosecution of activists and the excessively broad practice of the use of some provisions of the legislation, Memorial demands the scrapping of the article on repeat violations of the regulations governing the organization of rallies, insulting the feelings of believers, public calls for violations of Russia's territorial integrity, willful evasion of the observance of duties envisaged by the legislation on foreign agent NGOs, "revision of the practice of the use of the extremist legislation, serious revision and updating of the anti-extremist and counterterrorism legislation."

Dmitry Vyatkin, first deputy head of the State Duma Committee for the Development of Civil Society, told Interfax that "there are no political prisoners in Russia as we do not have political articles."

"Communities, organizations, citizens who start using terms such as 'political prisoners,' 'prisoners of conscience' pursue their goals, which are far from human rights protection as such," Vyatkin said. He said he believes that is "a consequence of the work that is being done against Russia, which consists of deliberate provocations, attempts to destabilize the situation." "We do not idealize the law enforcement system of any country, but the attempts to reduce everything to politics - no, it's not politics," he said.

"None of the articles stated [in the Memorial report] can be reversed, especially Article 282 (organization of an extremist community), it should be used and fulfill its function because dividing society, destabilizing, playing on low feelings, dividing [people] into first and second class [citizens] - these things are very dangerous, it may blow up any country," he said.

The human rights center Memorial has been on the foreign agent list since 2014.

Russian Supreme Court turns down prosecution's motion on reviewing ex-policeman Zakharchenko's case

MOSCOW. June 4 (Interfax) - The Russian Supreme Court has turned down a cassation motion by the Prosecutor General's Office on the case of Dmitry Zakharchenko, a former colonel of the Russian Interior Ministry's Anti-Corruption Directorate, who was sentenced to 12 years and six months of prison for bribery and obstruction of justice.

"The court turned down the motion on transferring the case to a cassation instance for hearing," the court's press service told Interfax on Wednesday.

The cassation motion was filed with the Supreme Court by Deputy Prosecutor General Viktor Grin, it said.

Moscow's Presnensky District Court ruled on June 10, 2019 to sentence Zakharchenko to 13 years in a high-security penitentiary for accepting a massive bribe and obstructing justice, fined him 117,990,000 rubles, and stripped him of his colonel's rank and decorations.

The first-instance court cleared Zakharchenko of one of the two bribery counts he was charged with and ruled that he was entitled to rehabilitation.

After hearing the prosecution's motion and the defense's complaints, the Moscow City Court ruled on October 17, 2019 to commute the prison term given to Zakharchenko to 12 years and six months. The court, however, left the extra punishments given to him, including the fine, unchanged.

The 2nd General Jurisdiction Cassation Court ruled on February 18, 2020 to uphold the judgments handed down in Zakharchenko's case. The court declined both the prosecution's motion, in which it requested that the count of which he was cleared be reviewed in a first-instance court, and the defense's complaint, in which it insisted on the former policeman's complete acquittal.

The investigation determined that Zakharchenko received a 50% discount card for the La Maree fish restaurant chain from businessman Mehdi Duss, which saved him about 3 million rubles.

The investigation and the court also determined that Zakharchenko had warned Galina Marchukova, the financial director of Nota Bank, of impending searches in 2016.

Zakharchenko was also charged with receiving, together with former Federal Security Service (FSB) officer Dmitry Senin, a $800,000 bribe from Duss, but the court cleared him of this crime.

In 2020, Zakharchenko was also charged with accepting bribes amounting to about 1.5 billion rubles, after which he was escorted from a penitentiary in Mordovia to Moscow to be familiarized with the new case.

Zakharchenko made headlines after detectives discovered cash in different currencies amounting in aggregate to an equivalent of some 8 billion rubles in his sister's apartment.

The former colonel, who was arrested back on September 10, 2016, described the criminal cases opened against him as fake.

Covid-19 vaccine developed jointly with Russian military ready for clinical trials

Fifty volunteers have been selected among Russian Armed Forces personnel for participation in the clinical trials, while the vaccine itself have already undergone tests for toxicity, safety, immunogenicity, and protective efficiency on large and small animals (monkeys and hamsters) at the 48th Central Scientific Research Institute of the Russian Defense Ministry, she said.

"All of them are serving under contract. They are warrant officers and officers aged between 25 and 50 years old, since legislation of the Russian Federation prohibits conducting trials on conscripts," Pozdnyakova said.

These 50 volunteers include ten healthcare workers, including three doctors.

Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu told President Vladimir Putin during a videoconference on May 26 that the 48th Central Scientific Research Institute of the Radiation, Chemical, and Biological Protection Troops of the Defense Ministry together with the Nikolai Gamaleya National Epidemiology and Microbiology Research Center are developing a recombinant vaccine for the novel coronavirus. Roscosmos on Crew Dragon's launch: It is very important to have two options of traveling to ISS

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The Russian state space corporation Roscosmos has welcomed Saturday's successful launch of the manned aircraft Crew Dragon in the U.S. and noted the importance of a co-existence of two transport systems that can deliver crews to the International Space Station.

"It is very important to have at least two opportunities to get to the station. Since you never know... Things have happened in space, and there should be at least two transport systems capable of ensuring the presence of crews from different countries on board the ISS," Roscosmos spokesman Vladimir Ustimenko wrote on Twitter.

Commenting on the successful launch of Crew Dragon, Ustimenko said, "What has happened should have happened a long time ago. Now not only the Russians but also the Americans will fly to the ISS. That's great!"

As reported earlier, a SpaceX capsule carrying two NASA astronauts docked at the ISS at 5:16 p.m. Moscow time on Sunday.

Crew Dragon, on board of which two NASA astronauts, Robert Behnken and Douglas Hurley, departed from Cape Canaveral in Florida on Saturday afternoon to reach the ISS in about 19 hours, is the first manned aircraft launched form the U.S. since 2011, when the final space shuttle mission was completed.

The two U.S. astronauts lifted off in SpaceX's Crew Dragon spacecraft on a Falcon 9 rocket from Launch Complex 39A in Florida at 3:22 p.m. EDT on May 30. Initially, the launch was due earlier on May 27 but ended up being delayed 15 minutes to blast-off due to bad weather.

The launch was performed under the contract between NASA and SpaceX on creating an aircraft and a launch vehicle for commercial manned missions to the ISS.

This Crew Dragon mission is the spaceship's last big trial before a NASA certification for regular commercial manned missions to the ISS. In March 2019, a similar pilotless spacecraft completed the first successful experimental spaceflight to the station.

Since 2011, U.S. astronauts had been using Russia's Soyuz spacecraft to reach the ISS. NASA pays Russia for seats on board a Soyuz spacecraft. In particular, This May, NASA agreed to pay Roscosmos $90.2 million for one seat on board the Soyuz, which is due to depart for the ISS on October.

Roscosmos head Dmitry Rogozin said on May 25 that Russia was following with interest preparations for the launch of the manned spacecraft Crew Dragon to the ISS. The return of Americans to this work will help increase the number of Russian cosmonauts on board the station, he said.

"It is with great interest that we're watching the preparations for this launch. We have several motives for this. Indeed, for the past nine years, since summer 2011, only Russia, only Roscosmos, has facilitated the delivery of all international crews to the ISS: Americans, Europeans, the Japanese, and Canadians," Rogozin said on the Komsomolskaya Pravda radio station.

"Yes, we have, of course, made some money on that, but in fact, the responsibility associated with supporting this transport system, the continual delivery to the ISS, has been colossal; it's not worth the money: the cost is nerves, the health of the people in charge of manned space," Rogozin said.

"We would be very happy if the Americans came up with an alternative manned transport system. It's a natural process, such a great power as the U.S., I imagine what they went through all these nine years, not being able to deliver astronauts to the ISS on their spacecraft [...] Let's wish them professional success," he said.

Russia is also interested in the technical side of the project, Rogozin said.

Unburdening Russian spacecraft will help increase the number of cosmonauts on the station, he said. "We've reduced our crews to two cosmonauts, who are in orbit continually. Sometimes there was only one, the captain, in orbit. This is wrong. This hinders the entire scientific program which we associate with the ISS," Rogozin said.

High-ranking Ukrainian delegation to discuss results of Normandy-format agreements in Berlin

KYIV. June 1 (Interfax) - A Ukrainian delegation will pay a working visit to Germany on June 2 to discuss the situation in Donbas, initiatives regarding Crimea, and the results of the Normandy-format agreements.

The delegation will include Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba and presidential chief of staff Andriy Yermak, the Ukrainian Foreign Ministry said in a statement on Monday.

While in Berlin, the delegation will meet with Foreign Minister Heiko Maas, the chancellor's Foreign Policy Advisor Jan Hecker, and Defense Minister Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer.

The parties will confer on a number of important aspects of bilateral cooperation, security policy, and the humanitarian situation in eastern Ukraine, the fulfillment of the decisions made by the heads of state and prime ministers at the Normandy-format summit in December 2019, the initiative regarding Crimea, and further coordination of efforts in mitigating the effects of the coronavirus pandemic, the statement said.

A joint press conference of the foreign ministers of Ukraine and Germany will be held at the end of the negotiations.

Roscosmos and NASA holding talks on mutual provision of seats aboard spacecraft bound for ISS

NUR-SULTAN. June 2 (Interfax) - Roscosmos and NASA are holding negotiations on providing seats for Russian cosmonauts and U.S. astronauts on each other's spacecraft to fly to the International Space Station (ISS), the Russian state space corporation's representative in Kazakhstan Anatoly Krasnikov said.

"We in the Roscosmos State Corporation are sincerely happy for our American colleagues, that their test mission of the Dragon spacecraft and its docking [with the ISS] went as planned and that everything worked out for them. We whole-heartedly congratulate them. This is a truly enormous success for them. This is great. The Roscosmos State Corporation and NASA are currently holding negotiations on mutual provision of seats for flights to the ISS," Krasnikov said at a press briefing on Tuesday.

"In other words, this is a situation where Russian cosmonauts will fly aboard American spacecraft, and American astronauts will continue flying on board our spacecraft," he said.

"Clearly, this is an urgent necessity, because all of us see now that a new transportation system has emerged to take humans to orbit, to the ISS, and of course people who fly there should know how to operate both one transportation system and the other transportation system," he said.

NASA and SpaceX successfully launched the Demo-2 mission last Saturday, sending the Crew Dragon spacecraft built by Elon Musk's SpaceX company into space. The astronauts docked with the ISS and entered the station on May 31.

Crew Dragon, carrying NASA astronauts Douglas Hurley and Robert Behnken, became the first U.S.-crewed spacecraft to lift off from U.S. soil since 2011, when the Space Shuttle Program was retired.

The SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket carrying the Crew Dragon spacecraft blasted off from the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral on May 30. The launch was initially expected to take place on May 27, but was postponed 15 minutes before takeoff due to adverse weather.

The launch was carried out under the contract between NASA and SpaceX to build a spacecraft and a launch vehicle for commercial flights of astronauts to the ISS.

Agreement on upgrading Gagarin's Start at Baikonur may be signed soon - Rogozin

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Roscosmos hopes to complete talks soon on upgrading the Gagarin's Start launch pad at the Baikonur Cosmodrome, head of Roscosmos Dmitry Rogozin said.

"What allows us to think today that Baikonur will live on and the city will develop? This is, above all, the continuation of the manned space flight program, which we tie to the restoration of Gagarin's Start. Such talks are currently in progress, and we hope they'll be completed soon and we'll start actual, physical work on this first, legendary launch pad," Rogozin said in a video address on the occasion of the 65th anniversary of Baikonur.

The future of the cosmodrome and the city is also linked to the Baiterek project, from which Soyuz-5 rockets will be launched, he said.

"And when these launch pads become operational, and as far as I understand, this will happen within the next few years, because the rocket itself is already being built at a Samara enterprise, then there will be further, very firm confidence that Baikonur will live on, not only in the programs for the future development of the Russian space sector, but it'll also become a crucial factor of connection between Russia and Kazakhstan," Rogozin said.

Kazakh Aerospace Committee Chairman Baubek Oralmagambetov said in February that Kazakhstan hopes to sign such an agreement in the first half of 2020.

At the beginning of June last year, the Russian Direct Investment Fund and investors from the United Arab Emirates signed an agreement with Roscosmos on allocating $90 million for the restoration of Gagarin's Start.

It was reported in December 2019 that the agreement between Russia, Kazakhstan, and the UAE on upgrading Gagarin's Start at the Baikonur Cosmodrome was undergoing approval procedures in the states themselves.

Rogozin said earlier that Russia, Kazakhstan, and the UAE would sign a trilateral agreement on the restoration of Gagarin's Start at Baikonur before the end of 2019.

The Gagarin's Start launch pad was closed after the launch of the last Soyuz-FG rocket on September 25, 2019.

Gagarin's Start, or Baikonur's Site No. 1, is the launch pad that was used for the world's first human spaceflight, made by Soviet pilot and cosmonaut Yury Gagarin on Vostok 1 on April 12, 1961.
