Dozens of thousands of unjustly convicted people in Russia, up to 1,000 political prisoners - human rights center

MOSCOW. June 3 (Interfax) - The human rights center Memorial has estimated the number of unjustly convicted people in Russia at dozens of thousands and the number of political prisoners at 2-3 times more than the 300 people Memorial knows of.

"The understanding of the state of the Russian law enforcement and judicial system makes it possible to believe it is probable that the number of innocent people whose guilt was not proven in accordance with the procedures established by the law in Russia is at least in the dozens of thousands. Such estimations are given by human rights experts and victims of this system, who had to personally experience it," Memorial told Interfax on Tuesday.

Moscow Memorial board member Sergey Davidis told the agency regarding the number of political prisoners, in other words, people prosecuted for political reasons, that "bearing in mind the number of existing cases which we know of and believe to have indications of political motivation and illegal prosecution in them, but which we could not investigate properly, I think the total number of political prisoners is 2-3 times more than the 314 people who are currently on our lists."

The number of known political prisoners has increased more than six times since 2015.

The Memorial report on the situation with politically motivated prosecutions states that "an overwhelming majority of political prisoners are people imprisoned in connection with the exercise of the right to freedom of religion and religious affiliation."

In regard of the prosecution of activists and the excessively broad practice of the use of some provisions of the legislation, Memorial demands the scrapping of the article on repeat violations of the regulations governing the organization of rallies, insulting the feelings of believers, public calls for violations of Russia's territorial integrity, willful evasion of the observance of duties envisaged by the legislation on foreign agent NGOs, "revision of the practice of the use of the extremist legislation, serious revision and updating of the anti-extremist and counterterrorism legislation."

Dmitry Vyatkin, first deputy head of the State Duma Committee for the Development of Civil Society, told Interfax that "there are no political prisoners in Russia as we do not have political articles."

"Communities, organizations, citizens who start using terms such as 'political prisoners,' 'prisoners of conscience' pursue their goals, which are far from human rights protection as such," Vyatkin said. He said he believes that is "a consequence of the work that is being done against Russia, which consists of deliberate provocations, attempts to destabilize the situation." "We do not idealize the law enforcement system of any country, but the attempts to reduce everything to politics - no, it's not politics," he said.

"None of the articles stated [in the Memorial report] can be reversed, especially Article 282 (organization of an extremist community), it should be used and fulfill its function because dividing society, destabilizing, playing on low feelings, dividing [people] into first and second class [citizens] - these things are very dangerous, it may blow up any country," he said.

The human rights center Memorial has been on the foreign agent list since 2014.

Equipped with an unmanned turret, it is the first tank where the crew is placed in an armored capsule separated from the ammunition load.

Solution of border issues between Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan doesn't require third parties' involvement, Dushanbe tells Moscow

DUSHANBE. May 29 (Interfax) - The Tajik Foreign Ministry has sent Russia a note concerning the statements made by Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov on the situation on the Tajik-Kyrgyz border, the republic's Foreign Ministry said on Friday.

On Tuesday, Lavrov called on Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan to refrain from using force in connection with the situation on the two countries' border.

"Concerning the situation on the border between Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan: unfortunately, such an incident has happened not for the first time. We're calling on our allies to join in a dialogue and refrain from using force as much as possible. We stand ready to offer our mediation services and believe that the sooner the situation normalizes, the better," Lavrov told journalists during a videoconference.

"The Tajik Foreign Ministry paid attention to the statements by Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov at a press conference following the meeting of the CSTO Council of Foreign Ministers on May 26, 2020 concerning the situation on the Tajik-Kyrgyz border. In this regard, a note was sent to the Russian Foreign Ministry on May 29, 2020, which stated that the said issue was not addressed in the meeting of the CSTO Council of Foreign Ministers," according to a report posted on the website of the Tajik Foreign Ministry on Friday evening.

"It was stated that activities in the sphere of delimitation and demarcation of state borders is an internal affairs of the CSTO countries and takes place solely on a bilateral basis. The Russian side was informed that the negotiation process on the solution of border issues between the Republic of Tajikistan and the Kyrgyz Republic takes place on a regular basis within the intergovernmental commission on issues relating to delimitation and demarcation of the Tajik-Kyrgyz border, and also working groups on legal and topographic issues, using advanced international practice and the provisions of relevant international legal instruments," the Foreign Ministry said.

In its note, the Tajik Foreign Ministry emphasized that the involvement of third parties in the negotiation process on the solution of border issues between the Republic of Tajikistan and the Kyrgyz Republic is unreasonable," the report said.

Kyrgyz and Tajik security forces exchanged fire over cattle pasturing in an area adjacent to the border between the two countries on Sunday.

"A border detail from Kyrgyzstan stopped the attempted grazing of cattle by residents of the Tajik exclave Vorukh in the Moinok area of the Batken district of the region of the same name in the Kyrgyz-Tajik sector of the state border. Unknown persons opened fire at Kyrgyz border guards from the side of Tajikistan," the Kyrgyz State Border Service said.

A Kyrgyz and a Tajik border detail exchanged fire later. No Kyrgyz border guards were injured, the border service said.

Meanwhile, Tajikistan accused Kyrgyz citizens of provoking the incidents.

"Despite the earlier agreements, Kyrgyz shepherds crossed into Tajikistan and had an altercation with residents of the border area. Rather than complying with the bilateral agreements which delimitate the border in disputed territories, Kyrgyzstan sent additional border details to the site, and they opened fire on unarmed people. A private was shot in the leg as a result of the shooting incident," the press center for the Border Forces of the Tajik National Security Committee said.

The Kyrgyz-Tajik section of the state border sporadically sees conflicts between local residents and border guards from both countries. The main reason for these conflicts is non-delimitated sections of the border. Out of about 980 kilometers of the borderline, more than 450 kilometers are neither delimitated, nor demarcated.

U.S. bombers perform air patrol mission over Ukraine

KYIV. May 29 (Interfax) - United States Air Force B-1B Lancer strategic bombers crossed Ukrainian airspace on Friday, after which they were joined and escorted by Ukrainian Air Force Sukhoi Su-27 and Mikoyan MiG-29 fighter jets, the Ukrainian Air Force reported on Friday.

Russian fighter aircraft were scrambled to intercept the U.S. bombers over the Black Sea and Baltic Sea, the Russian Defense Ministry said earlier on Friday.

Lukashenko pledges to protect Belarus's sovereignty so that Belarusians aren't sent to fight in Syria, Libya

MINSK. June 4 (Interfax) - Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko has pledged to do everything necessary to preserve Belarus's sovereignty and independence.

"We inherited the country and built our first independent and sovereign state. We won't give this country away to anyone and won't allow it to be tortured, destabilized day after day, torn into pieces and handed out," the Belarusian state-run news agency BelTA quoted Lukashenko as saying at a meeting on the composition of the new Belarusian government on Thursday.

There is an impression that certain potential presidential candidates "seek to destabilize and turn the country upside down using somebody else's money," he said.

"You and everyone else who hears me should remember that they won't get our country. We have spent over two decades picking up crumbs and building this prosperous country, and we won't allow anyone to privatize it and to bleed dry the unlucky fellows who have always lived under a whip," Lukashenko said.

"We won't allow Belarus to be divided, as happened in 1939," he said.

"We've built our country for our children. It's time we protect and defend it. As you can see, they're trying to tear us apart," Lukashenko said. "Some think everything will fall out of the sky. Watch out, or else you'll be sent to fight in Syria and Libya. God help us avoid fighting for our land and defending it," he said.

Newly Independent States

Some 50% of Ukrainians support integration with EU, more than 40% support Ukraine's accession to NATO - poll

KYIV. June 5 (Interfax) - A total of 46.1% of Ukrainians believe the country should join the European Union, and 41.9% of citizens support Ukraine's accession to NATO, according to a poll conducted by the Kyiv International Institute of Sociology (KIIS).

According to the poll, which was presented at the Interfax press center on Friday, 34.7% of Ukrainians believe that Ukraine should be a neutral state, 12% believe it should be a member of the Collective Security Treaty Organization (CSTO), 13.1% support the country's accession to the Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU), and 28.3% believe the country should not join any of those unions.

A total of 27.1% of respondents said they would move to the United States or the European Union to live there permanently, if they were granted U.S. or EU citizenship, and 65.1% said they would not do so. A total of 6.3% said they would move to Russia, and 86.3% said they would not do that. A total of 11.2% of respondents said they would move to Russia if they were given "$100,000 for relocation," while 80.2% said they would not do so.

The KIIS poll was conducted by phone between April 26 and April 30. A total of 1,500 interviews were conducted.

Trouble Spots

Presidents of Moldova, Transdniestria agree to facilitate Dniester crossing amid coronavirus pandemic

CHISINAU. June 3 (Interfax) - Moldovan President Igor Dodon and leader of the unrecognized Transdniestrian Moldovan Republic Vadim Krasnoselsky have agreed in a phone call to facilitate crossing of the Dniester River amid the coronavirus pandemic.

"I have pledged that Chisinau will prevent any steps or actions that could infringe on the rights of residents of the Transdniestrian region. Mr. Krasnoselsky and I expressed the shared opinion that everything necessary should be done to protect people from the virus," Dodon said on Facebook on Wednesday.

People from populated localities in the Dubasari district, which is a part of Moldova, but is located on the eastern bank of the Dniester River, have to travel through the populated localities of the Transdniestrian Moldovan Republic in order to cross the river. The Transdniestrian authorities closed their borders, including the border with Moldova, the moment the coronavirus state of emergency took effect.

It was agreed to facilitate traffic between the banks of the Dniester River. "Public health is of the utmost value, and it's also necessary to help deal with the socioeconomic consequences," Dodon said.

"During the phone call, opinions were exchanged on the Chisinau-Tiraspol negotiations and certain results of the activity of confidence-building working groups. It was agreed to continue the dialogue in order to solve problems and build up confidence between people on both banks of the Dniester," Dodon said.

The process of negotiations between Chisinau and Tiraspol was practically frozen after the coronavirus pandemic began. Moldova accused Transdniestria of being reluctant to cooperate, in particular, in humanitarian affairs and in the containment of the coronavirus pandemic. Tiraspol, in turn, accused Chisinau of creating artificial impediments to export/import operations, including the import of medicine. One reason for these problems is the shutdown of all Ukrainian checkpoints in the Transdniestrian section of the Moldovan-Ukrainian border because of the pandemic. As a result, Transdniestria has to conduct all of its trade via Moldova.

Border

Ukrainian serviceman detained for illegally crossing into Crimea - FSB

SIMFEROPOL. June 2 (Interfax) - A drunken Ukrainian serviceman has been detained for illegally crossing into Crimea, Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) said in a statement on its website on Tuesday.

"The trespasser has been identified as Ukrainian Armed Forces serviceman Ye. V. Dobrynsky, born in 1992," the statement said.

The man, "who was drunk and had no ID," was detained by Crimean border guards, it said.

An herbal substance, presumably a narcotic, was seized from the Ukrainian and sent to a lab for analysis.

A criminal case has been opened against the serviceman on counts of "illegally crossing the Russian state border," the statement said.

In turn, the Ukrainian military police said on Facebook on May 30 that "a serviceman of the Ukrainian Armed Forces stationed at an observation post went missing" in the vicinity of Chonhar in the Kherson region at about 5 a.m.

"The search for the missing serviceman was in vain. The serviceman is not answering his phone, and his whereabouts are unknown. According to the preliminary information, the serviceman was abducted in the line of duty. Traces of a struggle with unknown persons have been discovered near the observation post. Efforts are being undertaken to find him. The relevant materials were rapidly handed over to law enforcement authorities," the military police said.

The Armyansk, Dzhankoi, and Perekop border checkpoints are located in the north of Crimea. Their Ukrainian counterparts are Kalanchak, Chonhar, and Chaplynka.

Border

Ukrainian serviceman arrested in Crimea for one month in illegal border crossing case

SIMFEROPOL. June 4 (Interfax) - Simferopol's Kyivsky District Court ruled on Wednesday to arrest for 30 days Ukrainian serviceman Yevhen Dobrynsky, a defendant of the criminal case over the illegal crossing of the Russian state border, an Interfax correspondent reported from the courtroom.

"Deliver a measure of restraint in the form of a 30-day arrest term on Dobrynsky until July 1, 2020," Judge Valentina Kamynina said.

Investigators sought a term in custody for Dobrynsky, as he was trying to run away following the detention by border guards. Meanwhile, the Ukrainian has no lodgings in Crimea. A spokesperson of the prosecutor's office backed the plea. Lawyers and the defendant objected.

Resident of Ukraine's Rivne Region Yevhen Dobrynsky, 28, is an officer of the 95th Airborne Assault Brigade of the Ukrainian Armed Forces, and is married with a little child.

"I did not want to travel to Crimea, I did not seek to cross the border. I took a walk on the dam and wanted to look at fish," the serviceman said during the trial.

The defense team wants to appeal the first-instance court ruling in the Crimean Supreme Court, Islyam Velilyayev, a lawyer of the Ukrainian officer, told reporters.

Meanwhile, the Command of the Airborne Troops of the Ukrainian Armed Forces said the Russian special service's information about the condition of Dobrynsky during the detention is "Russia's predicted propaganda."

"The guy looks frustrated on the video [of the interrogation]. He is pronouncing the text prepared in advance. It is not ruled out that he is under the impact of special medications," the command of the Ukrainian Airborne Troops added.

The United States embassy to Ukraine expressed concern by the reports about the detention of the Ukrainian officer, American diplomats said in a brief message on social media sites.

As reported, the Ukrainian military police said on Facebook on May 30 that "a serviceman of the Ukrainian Armed Forces stationed at an observation post went missing" in the vicinity of Chonhar in the Kherson region at about 5 a.m., and said that he might be abducted, as "the traces of a struggle with unknown persons" were allegedly discovered.

Two days later, on June 2, the Russian Federal Security Service said that a drunken Ukrainian serviceman had been detained. A package, presumably containing a drug was seized from Dobrynsky. A criminal inquiry was launched against the Ukrainian for "the illegal crossing of the Russian state border."

Crimean border guards made public a video of the interrogation of the Ukrainian detainee on Tuesday evening.

He said he had been seconded for three months to protect a railway bridge and a dam in the area.

The serviceman said that he had a day-off on May 29, in the evening he went to the village of Sivash to buy cigarettes and met a group of local residents at a bus stop, they were drinking alcohol and smoking pot. These villagers invited the serviceman to join them and gave him a package containing drugs.

After that, the young man decided to take a walk on the dam.

"Strolling on the dam, I went down to the waterline, went off the dam, and sat on the rail track. Walking there, I noticed two armed people, I waved at them and said, 'Hi, do not shoot, I came with peace.' I was detained," the serviceman said.

"I was a little drunk. Local residents gave me a package, which contained cannabis," the detainee added.

Dobrynsky also said that he had no claims to Crimean border guards.

The Armyansk, Dzhankoi, and Perekop border checkpoints are located in the north of Crimea. Their Ukrainian counterparts are Kalanchak, Chonhar, and Chaplynka. A small buffer zone is located between Russian and Ukrainian border checkpoints.

Medical assistance provided to Whelan in untimely manner - U.S. embassy

MOSCOW. May 29 (Interfax) - The United States embassy to Russia has said it believes that medical assistance was provided to Paul Whelan, who has been charged with espionage in Russia, only when his condition became critical.

"Russian authorities waited until Paul Whelan's condition was life-threatening to provide him medical attention. That is unacceptable and dangerous," U.S. embassy spokesperson Rebecca Ross said on Twitter.

The U.S. repeatedly requested that an English-speaking doctor be allowed to see Whelan, but "he's been denied necessary medical attention," Ross said.

U.S. Ambassador John Sullivan spoke to Whelan on Friday, she said. "We will be monitoring Paul's progress closely, and we hope he will recover quickly," the U.S. diplomat said.

Whelan's brother said earlier that Whelan had undergone surgery for a hernia. The surgery was successful, he said.

Foreign Military Review

Germany suggests waiting for invitations to G7 summit, believes Russia may take part as guest - govt spokesperson

BERLIN. June 3 (Interfax) - Russia may well take part in a G7 summit in the United States in 2020 as a guest, but it would be reasonable to wait for an invitation from the U.S. before talking about this, German government spokesperson Steffen Seibert said on Wednesday.

"The decision on when such a summit is to be held rests with the host party. Concerning its format, guests have traditionally been invited to G7 summits. This is always a question for the host party. But if we're talking about changing the G7's format, such a decision must be agreed upon by all G7 members unanimously," Seibert said in response to a question from Interfax on Wednesday.

Having guests at the summit and an expanded format are different things, he said.

Seibert said this approach to all countries that may potentially be guests at the summit is a matter of principle.

"The format can be changed only provided that all the G7 countries adhere to the same position. Concerning Russia, there is a 2014 decision, when the G8 format existed, and the basis for this decision hasn't changed," Seibert said.

The 2014 decision was based on "the unlawful annexation of Crimea" by Russia, he said.

"The chance to change this state of affairs is in the Russian leadership's hands," Seibert said. He suggested waiting for any further announcements from U.S. President Donald Trump.

Trump earlier described the G7 format as inefficient and announced his intention to invite Russia, India, South Korea, and Australia to a summit to be hosted by the U.S. in 2020.
